title: dominoes-ace-norman-leaves-the-rest-chapping
story: THEY like their doubles at Nikis Bar.Not only did mine host Norman Mciver leave the rest chapping as he claimed the Galashiels Dominoes League coveted Piper Cup - for most inidual wins over the season - but he was also part of the winning league team.The win comes on the back of Nikis Numpties claiming the overall Galashiels Dominoes League title.But perhaps the most remarkable win of the dominoes season came at Gala Bowling Club.The knock-out finals featured the hosts, the British Legion, the Ladhope and Gala Fairydean Rovers.Despite trailing - in the semi-final Gala Bowling Club won six in a row to progress.And it was a similar story in the final against the Ladhope where they came from - down to win -.

title: serving-up-safety-is-celebrated-at-best-bar-none
story: PUBS, restaurants and hotels were recognised for serving up safety at the Best Bar None awards ceremony this week.Held at the Buccleuch Arms hotel in St Boswells, representatives from  licensed premises were rewarded for their commitment to making a night out that little bit better.And businesses from Eddleston to Eyemouth all received a gong, with the Queens Head in Kelso also in the running for a national award.Councillor John Greenwell, chairman of the Scottish Borders Licensing Board, who presented the awards, said: ldquoItrsquos really reassuring to see our bars taking customer care and safety seriously, which is what Best Bar None is all about.ldquoI congratulate all of our worthy winners and also wish the Queens Head the best of luck in the national finals.The prizes are broken into three level ndash gold, silver and bronze depending on how well a premises met the Best Bar None criteria.This yearrsquos gold winners were: Barony Castle , Buccleuch Arms Hotel , The Carters Rest , The Cobbles Inn , Coopers Bar , Liddesdale Hotel , Melrose Rugby Club, Oblo , The Plough Hotel , The Queenrsquos Head Hotel , Templehall Hoteland Town Arms Inn .The silver winners were: The Bridge Inn , The Cross Keys , Dryburgh Abbey Hotel and The Tavern Bar .The bronze winners were: The Bourtreeand Hunterrsquos Hall .Each premise is now accredited to the Best Bar None scheme.The Best Bar None Awards is supported by the Scottish Government, Scottish Borders Council, Police Scotland and Scottish Fire and Rescue Service.PC Nick Walker from the Scottish Borders Safer Communities Team and local Best Bar None lead, added: "We are grateful to everyone who took part in Best Bar None and it was great to see everyone getting their awards."Wersquore already looking ahead to this yearrsquos scheme, which will launch in the coming weeks, and I hope we can get even for premises signed up."For more information contact the Safer Communities Team on   or safercommunities@scotborders.gov.uk.

title: borders-set-for-role-in-digital-future-of-produce-markets
story: THE Scottish Borders is one of four Scottish regions set to share in pound, of EU funding, after a project to roll out click and collect farmersrsquo markets across rural Scotland was given the green light.Forth Environment Link, which runs Stirling NeighbourFood, will use the six-figure grant to establish eight new weekly markets across the Scottish Borders, Perth and Kinross, Forth Valley and Loch Lomond and Fe by .The NeighbourFood project aims to increase rural access to Scotlandrsquos larder by creating rural employment, offering small scale producers a safe route to market and connecting shoppers with the people who make or grow food locally.After registering for free, shoppers can place an order online using the NeighbourFood  and pick it up from a central venue ndash in Stirlingrsquos case, a local High School.The funding comes from a collaboration between four Scottish Rural Network LEADER programmes, as part of a wider EU funding programme aimed at supporting grassroots development of rural communities and businesses through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.As well as cutting down on waste, the initiative should see local producers rewarded fairly for their work.Jack Crotty, Director of NeighbourFood, explained how the model dfers from large retailers. He said: ldquoOur producers set their own prices and get to keep  percent of sales for every product, compared to - percent through supermarkets.ldquoThe remaining  percent is split equally between the market host and NeighbourFood.Since launching in Stirling in , the market has boosted the local economy by pound,, with producers keeping most of the profits.There is optimism in the Borders that the rollout of the project into the region will benefit the public as well as producers.Jane Rosegrant, Scottish Borders Leader Action Group Chair, said: ldquoScottish Borders LEADER is delighted to be supporting this innovative approach to making local food more accessible to local people.ldquoAt a time when sustainabilitymdashboth environmental and economicmdashis more important than ever, this project provides a practical way to provide fresh produce, cut food miles and support local producers all at the same time.The hunt is now on for eight new market hosts, who will be given funding, training and promotional support to set up the NeighbourFood scheme in their own area.Interested parties can register their interest in the scheme by contacting stuart@forthenvironmentlink.org.

title: borders-gardens-set-for-blooming-marvellous-festival
story: TWO Borders Gardens are set to show off their horticultural delights as they take part in this yearrsquos Scottish Rhododendron Festival.Dawyck Botanic Garden and Abbotsford will be representing the Borders in the annual festival, ing for its fth year, which runs from April  to May .The Scottish Rhododendron Festival is organised by national garden tourism group Discover Scottish Gardens, with support from VisitScotland, and comprises more than fty events across the country.Dawyck Botanic Garden, described by VisitScotland as ldquoa delight for Rhododendron enthusiasts, features an array of specimens gathered from the wild, with some now over  years old.Abbotsford, the ancestral home of Sir Walter Scott, will be running exclusive tours for the festival between May  and May .Paula Ward, VisitScotland Regional Leadership Director, hopes the participation of the two gardens will be of benefit to the entire region. She said: ldquoIrsquom thrilled to see that Dawyck Botanic Garden and Abbotsford are taking part in the Scottish Rhododendron Festival.ldquoWith the weather getting warmer, visitors will be able to see this magnicent plant flower as well as enjoy all that these attractions have to offer.ldquoThese visitors represent a major benefit to the region.ldquoTourism is more than a holiday experience, it is the heartbeat of the Scottish economy and touches every community, generating income, jobs and social change.Borderers may already have noticed an abundance of flowering Rhododendrons, with many species flowering early this year due to unseasonably warm weather.David Knott, curator at the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh, a world centre for rhododendron studies, said: ldquoThe warmer temperatures we have been experiencing provide optimum conditions for these exotic shrubs, originally from the East, to thrive.ldquoThe unusual weather and early flowering also highlight the impact of climate change on plants and flowering behaviour - a situation we will continue to monitor at the Botanics.

title: scotrail-cancellations-due-to-wrong-kind-of-staff
story: MSP Christine Grahame has criticised ScotRailrsquos lack of foresight relating to workforce planning after it emerged that a spate of recent cancellations was the result of a lack of trained staff.The CEO of ScotRail Abellio, Alex Hynes, was appearing before Holyroodrsquos Rural Economy and Connectivity Committee after the operator faced heavy criticism in the wake of numerous delays and cancellations.He was speaking to the committee following the publication of an pound million remedial plan, in response to being issued with an improvement notice by the Scottish Government in December because of low levels of passenger satisfaction.A further improvement notice was issued in February following multiple cancellations of services due to ongoing staffing issues.In the remedial plan ScotRail concedes that ldquothe service our customers have received has not been good enough recently and that the operator ldquoaccepts ultimate responsibility for the unacceptable service our customers have received.Mr Hynes announced that the recent cancellations ldquowere not due to not having enough train crew but instead ldquothey were due to not having enough train crew trained in the new routes and the new types of train.During the questioning it emerged that the operator had not previously employed anyone with overall responsibility for workforce planning.The Borders railway passes through Ms Grahamersquos constituency, and has been badly affected by recent service disruptions, with the MSP staggered by the apparent lack of planning.She said: ldquoIt would appear that ScotRail have recruited sufficient staff ndash indeed they currently have  applicants for driver roles ndash but have completely failed in planning for what routes theyrsquoll be needed on and when theyrsquoll be trained on them.ldquoThis is made all the clearer by the fact there has been no-one with overall responsibility for workforce planning, which is frankly astounding.ldquoI accept they have said they will now introduce this as a role, and that the new timetable was planned before the current CEO took charge, but I cannot imagine my Borders and Midlothian constituents, and passengers across Scotland, will be overly impressed at this lack of basic planning.ldquoMr Hynesrsquo explanation that they had enough staff, but not enough staff trained, rather brings to mind the lsquowrong kind of leavesrsquo on the line ndash only this time they had the wrong kind of staff.

title: innerleithen-opera-make-a-habit-of-great-shows
story: All is right in the kingdom of Innerleithen as the amazing Opera cast get back in the habit of raising the roof off the Memorial Hall with their stage adaptation of Sister Act.Its opening night for Innerleithen  District Operatic Society who are about to debut the musical comedy that hit our screens in .When clubland a Deloris Van Cartier played by Nicola Watt burst into song with her big hair, leopard print clothes and purple knee high boots, I was hooked.The story echoes that of the movie. Deloris is a Philadelphia lounge singer who dreams of stardom, but when she witnesses her lover-turned-gangster shoot one of his mob, she flees into the arms of good guy cop lsquoSweaty Eddiersquo .Delorisrsquo world is turned upside down when she is placed under witness protection in a rundown convent, disguised as nun Sister Mary Clarence.Although the adaptation does not feature songs from the original film, the musical repertoire is erse and magical.When we first catch a glimpse of the nuns, as they meander across the stage squawking like a bunch of demented penguins, I grimace. They are so out of tune I pray I donrsquot hear that god awful sound again.Upon learning that Deloris will be joining the convent, Mother Superior, played by Pam Graham, prays: ldquoDear Lordthis is a test, I cannot fail with you by my side. May she be of faith, of modestyhellip But she is stopped in her tracks by the voice of a brash American Deloris.Mother Superior continues: ldquoPerhaps the choir of angels drowned me out and you didnrsquot hear me Lord.Pam plays the exasperated Mother Superior prissy and clipped, with subtle comedy delivered in perfect tone.Of course things donrsquot run smoothly for the ghetto-fabulous a-turned-nun as you probably can imagine. It isnrsquot long before Deloris ruffles Mother Superiorrsquos habit and puts the nuns in danger, which leads to Deloris being given just one simple activity, joining the choir.Can she really unleash the songbirds trapped inside these nuns  This is when the show steps up a notch, and, although all dressed in habits, the audience can start to identy with the lead characters.In steps jolly Sister Mary Patrick, played by the enigmatic Claire Bell, along with Sister Mary Robertas the timid church mouse, and deadpan choir director Sister Mary Lazaruswho fully captured the gravelly voiced cantankerous nun. Her reprisal of the screen character is uncanny and garners lots of laughs from the audience.When the large ensemble of nuns gathered together, I did feel a sense of sisterhood and that they were each playing dferent characters despite having a minor role or no dialogue. Their pitch perfect delivery of lsquoRaise Your Voicersquo and lsquoTake Me To Heavenrsquo would draw the crowds into any church Irsquom sure.Playing the leading lady is no easy task, but in scene after scene Nicola embraces Deloris and puts her own sass and ghetto style into the character, belting out powerful tunes. To sum up her performance, what better words to use than those of Deloris Van Cartier herself ndash shersquos lsquoFabulous Babyrsquo!The last time I saw Lizzie Bell she was stumbling about drunk and shouting at a group of young kids, so I was shocked to see her convert to a Catholic nun. Of course, Lizzie was in character then as the vile orphanage boss Miss Hannigan, for Annie, performed by the Kids Innerleithen Theatre in November last year. The young actress shows true ersity, by portraying the meek Sister Mary Roberts with an enchanting solo performance.Although the female performances were powerful, they did not overshadow the male cast. Roger Brydon, Stewart Wilson and Colin Tweedie had me in tears as bumbling henchmen Joey, TJ and Pablo. Their comical performance of lsquoLady In The Long Black Dressrsquo didnrsquot leave females in the audience weak at the knees, but it did conjure up a few belly laughs!David Paterson was cast as Curtis who played the mob boss brilliantly, dominating the stage fiercely. And mild mannered officer Eddie Souterwho gave a cracking solo, proves he lsquoCould Be That Guyrsquo going from lsquoSweaty Eddiersquo to lsquoCool Copper, saving Deloris and winning her heart. A special mention to Jamie McCubbin, as the Irish Monsignor OrsquoHara ndashI closed my eyes Irsquod swear it was Father Ted!Needless to say the cast were at the top of their game, but anyone going to the show will no doubt be dazzled by the glitzy backdrop and detailed stained glass art of the fictional Catholic church. And the sensational costumes had more sparkle than a disco ballhellipand for habits, thatrsquos no mean feat.Sister Act had the congregation of the Memorial Hall hailing Hallelujah and taking us all to heaven, with what I can only sum up as a musical godsend.

title: asdas-arrival-drove-wilderhaugh-to-become-best-in-scotland
story: A GALASHIELS petrol station is officially the best in Scotland.And the boss of Shells Wilderhaugh Filling Station admits it was the arrival of supermarket competition which drove his company to success.Wilderhaughs retail manager Richard Garrie collected the Scottish Large Forecourt of the Year trophy during the Forecourt Trader Awards in London.Richard described his firms fightback following the arrival of a local supermarket four years ago, which knocked fuel volumes by  percent overnight.He said: "We thought long and hard about how to tackle this."We realised that one thing we can offer our customers that a local supermarket cant, is good old-fashioned service."Even before Shell did it we put our own local attendants back on the forecourt and customers really appreciated it."We also launched a ppl-off fuel promotion for six months, which meant we were ppl cheaper than the local Asda."The promotion is linked to buying a car wash, and has been so successful we still run it occasionally. Its essential to always create a buzz around the business."An pound, shop refit and the introduction of Spar three years ago has also helped boost business.Charity and promotional events such as Lucky Pump Day, run in conjunction with Cash for Kids, has also helped put Wilderhaugh on the map.The site has just re-signed with Shell for five years and has just raised its canopy to . metres to attract bigger vehicles used by local businesses.Richard added: "What a great honour it was to collect the award on behalf of the staff at Adam Purves. Weve been totally blown away by winning this award. Its a great boost for the guys, and recognition for everything weve achieved."Our Forecourt Trader award was in recognition for the passion and quality of service delivered by our team. We now have a site that matches this in appearance."

title: selkirk-booze-thief-has-sentence-deferred
story: A -year-old Selkirk man admitted stealing alcohol from a local shop he is banned from.James Birchall of Sentry Knowe pleaded guilty to stealing three bottles of spirits from the Co-operative store in High Street, Selkirk, last month and breaching his bail conditions.Sentence was deferred at Selkirk Sherf Court until May .

title: council-offers-upset-grave-families-loan-of-lifting-equipment
story: AN elderly Peebles couple claim they have been offered the lsquoloan of a lting machinersquo by the local authority after complaining about their family headstone being toppled.As previously reported, more than  headstones were taken down during a safety inspection earlier this year.And the majority of the memorials were lsquosocketedrsquo into the ground by the inspectors.Dozens of families have raised the concerns and made complaints to Scottish Borders Council over the destruction ndash among them are Richard and Kay Learmond A memorial plaque for Richardrsquos sister, Betty, who died in New Zealand was placed onto the family headstone.But following a recent visit to the cemetery they were shocked to find the memorial had been dismantled and lsquosocketedrsquo with the memorial plaque buried beneath ground.After making a complaint, the pensioners claim they were told they would have to lsquocorrect the headstonersquo themselves and they could borrow a lting machine.Kay told us: ldquoWe have never complained about anything before but this is awful.ldquoWhen we made our first complaint the girl from the council offered us the loan of a lting machine so we could correct the headstone - she added that they couldnrsquot pay for the damage.ldquoWersquove made a second complaint but havenrsquot heard back yet.The memorial plaque for Richardrsquos sister was originally on a wall at a cemetery in Dunedin.But when authorities in New Zealand planned to demolish the wall for expansion purposes the family decided it should be placed on the headstone of her parents, George and Mary, in Peebles.Kay told us: ldquoWe werenrsquot aware there was anything wrong with the headstone -we had, wersquod have had it sorted.ldquoIt was a lovely granite headstone, yet it has been desecrated.ldquoThe first we knew of this was when we went to visit the grave. It has been very upsetting.A total of  headstones were tested in Peebles Cemetery with  deemed unsafe during the five-weeks inspection.Among the many stones which have been lsquomade safersquo are memorials to babies and soldiers killed in the wars.Local MSP Christine Grahame has hit out at the treatment of Mr and Mrs Learmond as well as others who have been left distressed by the inspection.She told us: ldquoI understand the need to ensure headstones at cemeteries are safe but the way this was handled by the council was insensitive and in some cases badly deliveredldquoI have seen the way the headstone at Mr and Mrs Learmondrsquos family lair was ed - the engraved plaque buried crudely and unnecessarily ldquoI trust it will be properly reinstated and the family receive an apology from the council.ldquoThis is not the first and probably not the last time Scottish Border Council has failed to inform and consult my constituents and its time it learned to do so.,params: .pushScottish Borders Council is responsible for health and safety obligations to all employees, contractors and visitors to each of the graveyards.Although headstones are the responsibility of the lair-holder, due to the age of many graves tracing families is dficult.And a five-year rolling programme of safety checks began in September.The local authority claims it is only offering lting equipment when stonemasons are employed to restore the memorials.A spokesperson said: ldquoAs part of the headstone safety testing programme to ensure a series of cemeteries are safe for people to visit and work in, Mr Learmondrsquos family headstone in Peebles Cemetery was made safe by socketing ndash a technique which keeps the headstone upright with the majority of the inscription still visible for families and visitors to read.ldquoMr Learmond indicated he would contact a monumental mason to re-erect the headstone and we advised our staff could assist by lting the headstone out of the socket in preparation for the memorial being fully restored by the mason.

title: historic-sites-in-the-scottish-borders-open-for-the-summer
story: Historical sites in the Scottish Borders are reopening now for the summer season.Historic Environment Scotland , which manages over  historical properties in Scotland and  in the Borders, has launched its events programme for the summer .Hermitage Castle, with its murky stories of the past and its beautul wildle, and Smailholm Tower, known for the stunning views that inspired Sir Walter Scottrsquos, will open the doors for the season on Monday  April.Dryburgh Abbey will host a Easter Eggsplorer Trail over the Easter weekend, when visitors will be given clues to complete challenges, while exploring the iconic structure.You can get your tickets for the Easter trail in advance online and save % or get them directly on the day. Historic Scotland members enter for free.Stephen Duncan, Director of Commercial  Tourism at HES, said: ldquoThe start of the season is always an exciting time for us, as we get ready to welcome new and ing visitors to our sites across the country, including the Borders.ldquoAt Historic Environment Scotland we are passionate about being able to provide experiences that allow locals and visitors to explore Scotlandrsquos rich heritage. Our  schedule offers a great way to discover Scotlandrsquos past, and wersquore really looking forward to welcoming everyone to our venues across the Borders and further afield.You can check out the detailed events programme by visiting www.historicenvironment.scot visit-a-place whats-on. Membership gets you unlimited access to HES sites, you can find more information at historicdaysawait.scot

title: everton-find-the-grave-of-championship-winning-goalkeeper
story: FOLLOWING an appeal in last weeks paper, heritage researchers have found the grave of the goalkeeper who helped Everton win their first Championship.David Jardine also became the Merseyside clubs first keeper to ever play at Goodison Park in .The son of a stonemason from Dumfriesshire died a cottage between Biggar and Coulter on March , .Everton Heritage Society carry out several research projects each year to locate the graves of prominent former players and hold rededication ceremonies.They have already erected headstones for two other players from north of the Border, Andrew Hannah and Sandy Young, who were buried in unmarked graves.Despite extensive searches around Biggar as well as family plots at Elvanfoot and Applegarth in Dumfriesshire, they couldnt find the grave of David Jardine.And a search had begun in the rural graveyards around Tweeddale.But just hours after we published an appeal, information has led the historical group to the goalkeepers grave - in a church yard that had already been checked.Tony Onslow from Everton Heritage Society told us: "Davids we Sarah is buried at Elvanfoot and we carried out checks which showed he isnt buried with her."But we didnt think to check the rest of the graveyard."We have now received information that hes buried in plot  where as Sarah is in ."We will be travelling up from Liverpool soon to visit his grave."

title: folk-royalty-rolls-into-selkirk
story: HES rightly regarded as folk Royalty.And next week Martin Carthy will show the String Jam Club audience exactly why.If the English folk revival of the s had a father-figure and guiding spirit, then Martin Carthy would be it.As the Letime Achievement Award winner at BBC Radio  Folk Awards in , Martin makes a welcome third visit to String Jam Club on Saturday, April .For more than  years he has been one of folk musics greatest innovators, one of its best loved, most enthusiastic and, at times, most quietly controversial of figures.His skill, stage presence and natural unassuming charm have won him many admirers, not only from within the folk scene, but also far beyond it.String Jam promoter Allie Fox told us: "If you trace Martins career from that period to the modern day, you have perhaps the most important and influential folksinger in England, a source of inspiration for many, a conduit for the songs, a genius guitar player who uses tunings you never knew existed, a model for how to approach traditional music, and in short a legend."In  Martin was awarded an MBE for his services to folk music."This is a wonderful opportunity to see and hear this folk icon live and up close at String Jam Club."Martin has been described as ldquoarguably the greatest English folk song performer, writer, collector and editor of them all by Q Magazine. Hersquos a ballad singer, a ground-breaking acoustic and electric-guitarist and an authoritative interpreter of newly composed material.Perhaps, most signicant of all, are his settings of traditional songs with guitar, which have influenced a whole generation of artists on both sides of the Atlantic, including Bob Dylan who first met Martin in the early s and has described him as ldquoincredible and Paul Simon, who notoriously used Martinrsquos arrangement of lsquoScarborough Fairrsquo for his hit single.Martin has long been regarded as one of the most pivotal figures in the English folk revival of the s, his vocal and guitar style being two of the most consistent, distinctive and influential sounds on the scene.Martin will play at the County Hotel in Selkirk on Saturday, April Doors open at .pm.Tickets, priced at pound, are available online from Eventbrite or in person from the County Hotel. To reserve tickets, email thestringjamclub@gmail

Her deal is now dead. The PM must now do the right thing ndash immediately revoke Article  and give the British public the final say on Brexit. #BrexitDayTodayrsquos outcome was entirely predictable.No amount of parliamentary trickery can breathe le back into Mayrsquos deal. The only route to resolve the crisis is a final say with the option to Remain in the EU.mdash Vince CableMarch , SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackfordsaid the time was right to now revoke Article  and hold a general election.He said: ldquoWe must give ourselves time and I suggest to her we now must look seriously at the option of revocation ndash we need to apply the handbrake to this process.ldquoThe Prime Minister has failed to take this deal forward and she does not have the confidence of the House.ldquoThe Prime Minister has indicated her departure. She should now go and we should be having a general election..pmReaction from across the political ide: Scotland First Minister Nicola Sturgeon tweeted:Third defeat for PMrsquos bad deal ndash she must now accept that itrsquos dead. The Commons will nowon Monday to find a way forward. I hope that willl be to put the issue back to the people and or revoke Article  ndash but @theSNPwill work with others to find the best option possiblemdash Nicola SturgeonMarch , Labour MP Stephen Kinnock told the Press Association: ldquoItrsquos another comprehensive defeat for the Prime Minister.ldquoWe have to now move into a new ball game really which is about turning the Political Declaration into something that can command a Parliamentary majority.--vw,vw,px, px"The tellers line up to deliver the result of the vote on the Governmentrsquos Withdrawal Agreement --Former Brexit minister Steve Baker, deputy chairman of the European Research Group, said it was time for Theresa May to quit.He said: ldquoThis must be the final defeat for Theresa Mayrsquos Deal. Itrsquos finished. And we must move on.ldquoIt has not passed. It will not pass. I regret to say it is time for Theresa May to follow through on her words and make way so that a new leader can deliver a Withdrawal Agreement which will be passed by Parliament.ldquoThis has been a tragic waste of time and energy for the country. We can waste no more.DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds urged Theresa May to ldquolook seriously at Dominic Raabrsquos comments on the Irish backstop.He said: ldquoShe knows that remains the problem hellip Please Prime Minister, even now, use the time constructively to get that matter sorted out..pmLabour leader Jeremy Corbyn called for Mrs May to step aside and for a general election to be held.Mr Corbyn said: ldquoThis is now the third time the Prime Ministerrsquos deal has been rejected. When it was defeated the first time, the Prime Minister said it was clear this House does not support the deal.ldquoDoes she now finally accept this House does not support the deal  Because she seemed to indicate just now that she is going toto this issue again.ldquoOn Monday, this House has the chance, and I say to all members, the responsibility to find a majority for a better deal for all the people of this country.ldquoThe House has been clear this deal now has to change. There has to be an alternative found.ldquoIf the Prime Minister canrsquot accept that then she must go. Not at an indeterminate date in the future, but now, so that we can decide the future of this country through a general election..pmThere were cheers from some factions in Parliament Square after Mayrsquos Commons defeat was announced, but where the reaction was muted with many people expecting the third vote on the deal to fail.One Leave protester asked the Press Association: ldquoSo what does that mean  Are we leaving on April  or not --vw,vw,px, px"The March to Leave protesters make their way through London --Nigel Farage joined the March to Leave procession around Tate Britain, less than a mile from Parliament Square.Asked when he wanted Brexit he said: ldquoTonight at  orsquoclock.Mr Farage told the Press Association ldquoFrom Sunderland itrsquos a bloody long way and congratulated those marchers who had walked the whole distance.He said: ldquoItrsquos a hell of an achievement and the symbolism couldnrsquot have been greater.ldquoI wouldrsquove liked to have done more, Irsquove just been too busy.ldquoI did a few days of it ndash and as commentators noted ndash I set a very fast pace..pmResponding to the vote result, European Council President Donald Tusk tweeted:In view of the rejection of the Withdrawal Agreement by the House of Commons, I have decided to call a European Council on  April. #Brexitmdash Donald TuskMarch , .pmMrs May went on: ldquoThe European Union has been clear that any further extension will need to have a clear purpose and will need to be agreed unanimously by the heads of the other  member states ahead of April . ldquoIt is also almost certain to involve the UK being required to hold European parliamentary elections. ldquoOn Monday, this House will continue the process to seethere is a stable majority for a particular alternative version of our future relationship with the EU. Of course, all of the options will require the Withdrawal Agreement. ldquoI fear we are reaching the limits of this process in this House. This House has rejected no-deal. It has rejected no Brexit. On Wednesday it rejected all the iations of the deal on the table, and today it has rejected approving the Withdrawal Agreement alone and continuing a process on the future. ldquoThis Government will continue to press the case for the orderly Brexit that the result of the referendum demands..pmThe Prime Minister said the implications of the vote were ldquograve adding:.pm.pmAs MPs voted, Liberal Democrat Layla Moran tweeted that the lsquonorsquo lobby was ldquoheaving.No lobby heaving. Lots of leavers here. Defeated roundly I predict.mdash Layla MoranMarch , Meanwhile, senior Tory MP and chairman of the European Scrutiny Committee, Sir Bill Cash, said ldquoit is unconscionable that Parliament be ldquopolitically castrated by passing the PMrsquos Withdrawal Agreement.It is unconscionable that this House should be politically castrated by voting for this Withdrawal Agreementmdash Bill CashMarch , .pmLabour MP Wes Streetingintervened during Mrs Mayrsquos final remarks, to dig at those who may see themselves as the next Tory leader: ldquoShe may have sacriced her career to put the country first, but there are plenty of people who aim to follow her whorsquove always put themselves first above the country.Independent Group MP Anna Soubry tweeted that Jacob Rees-Mogg had joined Boris Johnson in voting for the Prime Ministerrsquos deal.Principle counts for nothing as #JacobReesMogg#BorisJohnsonchange their mind and vote for #PMDealPity the British people canrsquot have the same right to change their mind@peoplesvote_uk@TheIndGroupmdash Anna Soubry MPMarch , .pmMore from the PMrsquos final plea to MPs before they voted: ldquoIf this motion carries today, we will bring forward a Withdrawal Agreement Bill.She added: ldquoBy voting for this motion, members are not closing any doors. They will still have the ability through the agreement bill to influence that future relationship.ldquoTodayrsquos motion is not about a blind Brexit. It is about a guaranteed Brexit.Mrs May continued: ldquoI am prepared to leave this job earlier than I intended to secure the right outcome for our country.ldquoAnd when the Division Bell rings in a few momentsrsquo time, every one of us will have to look into our hearts and decide what is best for our constituents and our country.Her words were not enough for Tory Romford MP Andrew Rosindell, who tweeted:I will vote today to uphold a true BREXIT to take Britain OUT of the Europe Union that I have always believed in and that my country and my constituents of Romford voted for ndash our United Kingdom must be a sovereign nation again and I will not compromise on that! ##mdash Andrew Rosindell MPMarch , .pmWhile MPs are voting inside the Commons, outside the protests are continuing:A grim state of affairs outside the @HouseofCommons. A flute band playing and as they passed I saw someone doing a Nazi salute.**There is no emoji for what Irsquom feeling. Sick doesnrsquot cover it. pic GzaiJyShmdash Hannah Bardell #########zwj#March , .pmAnd with a roar of ldquoDivision Speaker John Bercow clears the Commons as MPs go to vote on the latest stage of the Withdrawal Agreement..pm--vw,vw,px, px"--Mrs May is closing the debate and told the Comons: ldquoToday should have been the day the UK left the EU ndash that we are not leaving today is a matter of deep personal regret to me.ldquoBut I remain committed to the UK leaving the EU and that is why I brought this motion to the House today.ldquoThere are those who will say lsquothe House has rejected every option so far, yoursquoll probably lose so why bother rsquo ndash I bother because this is the last opportunity to guarantee Brexit.ldquoAnd I say to all those who campaigned to leave, who voted to leave, who represent constituencies that voted leave, indeed all of us who want to deliver on the vote to leave,we do not vote for this motion today people will ask lsquowhy did you not vote for Brexit rsquo.ldquoBy voting for this motion today we can send a message to the public and European Union that Britain stands by its word and that wersquoll leave the European Union on May .--vw,vw,px, px"Theresa May speaks in the House before the vote --.pmAs Jeremy Corbyn addressed the Commons, MP Nadine Dorries tweeted that the Conservative benches were yet to fill because:There are a number of meetings taking place were decisions are being taken. Itrsquos going to the wire. https:t.co euAydVmdash Nadine DorriesMarch , .pmAs the voting time of .pm draws near, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has been speaking in the debate, calling the proceedings ldquoaffront to democracy.He said: ldquoThe Government has run down the clock in an attempt to blackmail MPs at every turn.ldquoThe country is in chaos and responsibility for this chaos is the Governmentrsquos, and the Governmentrsquos alonehellipldquoTodayrsquos vote ndash third time lucky the Prime Minister hopes ndash is an affront to democracy and an affront to this country.This afternoon, the Prime Minister is asking MPs to vote for a blind Brexit.This young womans words are as true today as they were last week. pic VzOIbCIFsmdash Jeremy CorbynMarch , .push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Brexit Live: MPs vote against Withdrawal Agreement for a third time

title: council-plans-could-mean-last-orders-for-public-drinkers
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has launched a consultation to gauge public opinion on the drinking of alcohol in public spaces, with the possibility of a byelaw banning public drinking being introduced.Currently, legislation pertaining to public alcohol consumption is decided by local councils, with some enforcing byelaws to prevent drinking in public.The Borders is one council area where public alcohol consumption is not currently outlawed.However, the council are keen to hear from Borderers to establish whether people think the drinking of alcohol in any public areas is causing problems.An online survey will be accessible until May  and the council is keen for locals to voice their opinions on the matter.Paper surveys will also be available in council contact centres and local libraries.If the drinking of alcohol in public places is identied as an issue, a second consultation will take place to understand the level of support for byelaws to be introduced to clamp down on public drinking.If the council did decide to act, they would reserve the right to suspend any byelaw during events such as common ridings, local festivals and new year celebrations.Councillor Shona Haslam, Leader of Scottish Borders Council, said: "As a council we considered this proposition a few years ago but we felt that we needed to hear from local communities before taking this further.ldquoDo you think that they are needed ldquoDo you think that they should be town wide, or specic to certain areas ldquoDo you think that this a necessary or unnecessary step for the Council to take ldquoAny ban would not stop people drinking in their gardens, beer gardens or at licensed events, but we want to know of any potential problem areas that the public think such a ban would be helpful.The online survey, alongside further information about the consultation, can be accessed at https:scotborders.citizenspace

title: brexit-set-for-long-delay-after-mps-turn-down-withdrawal-agreement
story: Brexit appears to be on course for a y delay after MPs rejected Theresa Mayrsquos EU Withdrawal Agreement by a margin of  votes.In dramatic scenes in the House of Commons, MPs voted by  to  against the deal as hundreds of protesters staged a noisy demonstration outside on the day when the UK was due to leave the European Union.----Some  Conservative rebels ignored a last-ditch plea from the Prime Minister to take ldquothe last opportunity to guarantee Brexit and consigned her deal to its third humiliating defeat.The result of the crunch vote means that the UK has missed an EU deadline to secure an extension of the Brexit process and leave with a deal on May .Mrs May now has until April  to go back to Brussels with new proposals and seek a longer extension to the negotiation process, or see the UK leave without a deal that day.----With a clear majority in the Commons against no-deal, and with MPs once more seizing control of the timetable on Monday, Mrs May said the UK would have to find ldquoan alternative way forward.This was ldquoalmost certain to involve the UK having to stage elections to the European Parliament in May, she said.Mrs May said that the outcome was ldquoa matter of profound regret.Despite the setback, Downing St said it was not an ldquoinevitability that the UK would have to participate in the European elections and made clear she would continue to fight for her deal.After defeats of  and  in the previous two Commons votes, a No  source said they were ldquoat least going in the right direction.ldquoWe continue to believe that the deal the PM has negotiated is the best outcome for the country and we will continue to seek a way forward, the source said.European Council president Donald Tusk called an emergency summit of EU leaders in Brussels on April  to discuss the implications of the vote.In view of the rejection of the Withdrawal Agreement by the House of Commons, I have decided to call a European Council on  April. #Brexitmdash Donald TuskMarch , Labour leaderJeremy Corbyn called for a general election unless the Prime Minister was willing to find an alternative deal.And Mrs May ndash who had promised to step down as Prime Ministerher deal was approved ndash appeared to hint that this was a possibility, telling MPs: ldquoI fear we are reaching the limits of this process in this House.--vw,vw,px, px"The vote took place amid noisy demonstrations on Parliament Square --She said: ldquoThis House has rejected no deal. It has rejected no Brexit. On Wednesday it rejected all the iations of the deal on the table.ldquoAnd today it has rejected approving the Withdrawal Agreement alone and continuing a process on the future.ldquoThis Government will continue to press the case for the orderly Brexit that the result of the referendum demands.--vw,vw,px, px"Jeremy Corbyn demanded a general electionthe Prime Minister was not willing to change course --Mr Corbyn told MPs: ldquoThe House has been clear this deal now has to change, there has to be an alternative found.ldquoAndthe Prime Minister canrsquot accept that then she must go ndash not at an indeterminate date in the future but now, so that we can decide the future of this country through a general election.The deputy chairman of the European Research Group of Tory Eurosceptics, Steve Baker, called on Mrs May to step down immediately.Declaring that this should be ldquothe final defeat for the PMrsquos deal ndash already rejected by  votes in January and  in March ndash Mr Baker said: ldquoI regret to say it is time for Theresa May to follow through on her words and make way so that a new leader can deliver a Withdrawal Agreement which will be passed by Parliament.--vw,vw,px, px"--The fate of Mrs Mayrsquos deal was sealed as  Conservative MPs went through the No lobby, while only five Labour MPs voted with the Prime Minister.The number of Tory rebels was fewer than half the  who opposed the deal in the Meaningful Vote of March  but enough to overturn the result had they voted the other way.Among rebels were hardline Brexiteers including Mr Baker, Sir Bill Cash, Priti Patel, Owen Paterson and Sir John Redwood, along with supporters of a softer deal like Dominic Grieve, Justine Greening and Sam Gyimah.--vw,vw,px, px"--Labour MPs backing the deal were Kevin Barron, Rosie Cooper, Jim Fitzpatrick, Caroline Flint and John Mann,along with the partyrsquos former MPs Frank Field and Ian Austin, now sitting as independents.DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds said Mrs May had missed ldquonumerous opportunitiesto remedy the ldquodeficiencies in proposed backstop arrangements for the Irish border, which made the deal unacceptable to his party.ldquoOver the coming weeks and months, we will continue to play a central role to chart a route that respects the democratic desire to leave the European Union but that does so in a way that strengthens our United Kingdom, said Mr Dodds..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Brexit set for long delay after MPs turn down Withdrawal Agreement

title: brexit-marchers-confused-on-day-they-planned-to-celebrate
story: Protesters who expected to celebrate Brexit outside Parliament were instead left confused by the latest defeat of Theresa Mayrsquos plans.Some cheered when the Prime Minister suffered another Commons defeat when her Withdrawal Agreement was rejected on Friday ndash the slated deadline for the departure.But others were left fearing it meant a new EU referendum was now on the cards and were frustrated by a delay.The March to Leave started in Sunderland two weeks ago. It was joined by prominent Brexiteer Nigel Farage near Tate Britain, which is less than a mile from the destination of Parliament Square.The new EU treaty has been rightly defeated for a third time. Extension and further battles now seem inevitable.We are not downhearted, and will fight them again. pic nEGIIsYXDImdash Nigel FarageMarch , Mr Farage celebrated the defeat of Mrs Mayrsquos ldquoappalling agreement, saying he would rather have an extension to Article  or leave with no deal immediately.ldquoIf there are more battles to come be they European elections or whatever  thatrsquos what wersquoll focus our energies on, he told the Press Association.Thousands of protesters gathered outside Parliament, and at least two MPs have said they were abused during the demonstrations.Joanna Cherry QC, the SNP MP for Edinburgh South West, said on Twitter: ldquoVery relieved to be safely back to my base in London. Was abused by trailing ends of the #LeaveMeansLeave protest as I walked home. Called a traitor. Told to go back to my own country. Such a contrast from #PeoplesVoteMarch last weekend #BrexitChaos.Today outside Parliament I and others were accosted by people shouting f****** traitor as we tried to get in to vote. Our staff were advised to leave the building for their own safety. There were armed police everywhere. This is not normalmdash Lisa NandyMarch , The Labour MP for Wigan, Lisa Nandy, tweeted: ldquoToday outside Parliament I and others were accosted by people shouting f****** traitor as we tried to get in to vote. Our staff were advised to leave the building for their own safety. There were armed police everywhere. This is not normalThe reaction of some protesters reinforced how confusing the Brexit process has been, with some wrongly believing it was a third ldquomeaningful vote on Mrs Mayrsquos deal.Danny Wallace, , from Manchester, said: ldquoI listened to what happened and Theresa May pretty much said shersquos going to come out with a second referendum.ldquoThatrsquos a bad idea, I think what most people wanted was what was on the table.Crowds chanting they want Brexit immediately as the March to Leave procession of hundreds reaches Pimlico on the original #BrexitDay#BrexitMarchpic tNbDoNEQmdash Thomas HornallMarch , Roger Hopkins and Charlotte Clford, both from Eastbourne, said they were pleased the agreement had been defeated as it was a ldquobad deal.Mr Hopkins, who is retired, said: ldquoWhat I really really hope for now is to come out on WTOterms, itrsquos not lsquocrashing outrsquo or anything like that.Ms Clford added: ldquoThe people are supposed to be the masters and them insideare meant to do what we tell them. Itrsquos democracy.Tommy Robinson, the English Defence League founder who now advises Ukip, acknowledged the confusion to cheering fans.Pro-Brexit protesters staging a road block outside Parliament @PApic lGPqiADxmdash Tess de la MareMarch , ldquoSo Theresa May has lost her vote. Many people will be asking what does that even mean, said the activist, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon.ldquoIt means we were betrayed. Today is supposed to be our Independence Day.The final leg of the March To Leave saw hundreds of marchers file from Fulham towards Parliament Square.Wearing a kilt and wielding a Saltire flag Brexit Party MEP for Scotland David Coburn, formerly of Ukip, said of the march: "Excellent, isnt it  Its like Cromwells Army."#Brexit#BrexitMarchpic tlSMhcQrmdash Thomas HornallMarch , Former Ukip leader Mr Farage was to address the crowds in Parliament Square ndash whereas the partyrsquos current leader, Gerard Batten, spoke alongside Mr Robinson from a stage in Whitehall.Scotland Yard was compelled to dismiss as ldquobaseless and  suggestions from Mr Batten that water cannon could be deployed at protests to ldquoprovoke Brexiteers.The politan Police did have three water cannon ndash purchased while Boris Johnson was London Mayor ndash but they were sold at a more than pound, loss because their use had been banned.Westminster Council said it is aware of up to  separate scheduled protests and the politan Police said ldquoappropriate policing plans are in place.Scotland Yard said: ldquoWe will always provide a proportionate policing plan to balance the right to peaceful protest, while ensuring that disruption to communities is kept to a minimum..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Brexit marchers confused on day they planned to celebrate

title: irish-opposition-voice-disappointment-at-rejection-of-brexit-deal
story: Opposition leaders in Ireland have voiced their disappointment at rejection of the Withdrawal Agreement in the House of Commons.MPs voted to reject the deal for a third time on Friday.Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald said the ldquopolitical circus at Westminster was increasing the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit."The DUP have been seduced by the political games at WM. I think that they have forgotten the farmers, the business community, workers and the families who now view the chaos at Westminster, and the prospect of a crash Brexit, with absolute dismay." ndash @MaryLouMcDonald#BrexitDaypic nlNoVmLBImdash Sinn FeacuteinMarch , ldquoThe behaviour of the DUP has been reckless and outrageous, she said.ldquoThey have been seduced by the games at Westminster at the cost of farmers, the economy and the views of the majority in the north.ldquoOur economy, the rights of citizens and our hard-won agreements cannot be collateral damage to Westminster.Ms McDonald said the EU had made it clear that the Withdrawal Agreement would not be reopened, renegotiated or its protections reduced.ldquoThere cannot be a hard border across Ireland, she said.ldquoNow is the time for resolute and determined leadership.Sinn Fein is due to meet EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier and other European leaders in Brussels on Monday.ldquoWe will be pressing the case that in a crash-out Brexit, the EU must continue to act in the interests of all Ireland and support for our agreements, rights and economy, she said.Fianna Fail leader Micheal Martin said a further extension to Article  was needed to ease tensions.ldquoWe now are in an extremely serious situation, Mr Martin told RTE Radio One.ldquoItrsquos time perhaps to give time to it in terms of an extension and to calm things down.He added that a ldquopressure cooker atmosphere had enveloped Westminster but that politicians needed to remember that peoplersquos livelihoods were at stake.ldquoA no deal would be devastating for the agri-food industry in Ireland. It would devastate the British economy, and the time for putting politics before the livelihoods of people is long over, he said.ldquoTherersquos a need now to think of businesses, to think of jobs.The partyrsquos Brexit spokeswoman Lisa Chambers said a no-deal Brexit remained a distinct possibility and that intensive efforts must now be made to avoid such a ldquocatastrophic outcome.Where to next ! MPs reject the #BrexitWithdrawal Agreement for a third time. Tough decisions need to be made and we must do all we can to avoid a lsquono-dealrsquo Brexit, this has to be the one thing we all agree on. pic fytjHDmmdash Lisa Chambers TDMarch , Ms Chambers said she hoped that common sense would prevail in the UK, but she said clarity was needed from the Irish government on what would happen in the event of a no-deal Brexit.ldquoThe clock is winding down and it is incumbent upon the Irish government to ensure that the general public and members of the Oireachtas are fully aware of how it plans to traverse a no-deal exit should it come to pass, she said..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Irish opposition voice disappointment at rejection of Brexit deal

title: letter budget winners and losers
story: Another year and another budget for the council and as always there are winners and losers.I have to congratulate all the officers of the council, particularly Kirsty Flanagan, head of strategic finance and her team, for being so helpful during this process.I also thank the leader of the council for the manner in which the papers were presented this year which made alternative motions possible.However what did this year yield The main dferences in the budget came down to the administration of the council proposing £, more for winter gritting, outwith the A which is covered by the contract with BEAR.This was against cuts in the road safety unit, an award-winning safety programme for young children, a cut in youth and adult learning, a cut in environmental warden services, which means a focus on more fines but less time for fly tipping and dog fouling and a cut to music tuition in schools.There were amendments lodged by Councillor Donald Kelly and myself, the SNP group and councillors George Freeman and Jean Moffat.While gritting our roads is important Councillor Kelly and I, along with other council opposition groups, thought the other considerations were important to our communities which strangely enough is also supported by our corporate plan.Alas the gritting won the day.Full motions and votes can be found on the council website.However it was more disappointing that Councillor Kelly and I included in our motion a scheme to change funding due for Helensburgh and Dunoon.Just more than £ million would be moved to the regeneration project of Tarbert Lochgilphead Ardrishaig.This was defeated by the rest of the council which was particularly galling.Money for Helensburgh had been questioned by its community council which felt that too much had already been spent.The money for Dunoon was because of poor procurement processes and a general #I want syndrome# all to the detriment of this its area.It is local democracy at work which should be communicated to our communities.Councillor Douglas Philand,

title: letter live argyll price increase
story: I have just received three envelopes from ‘ Live Argyll’ in Oban.On opening the first I found it to be leaflet headed #We’ve taken the £££’s OFF with our new membership prices#.I am well aware that you know what is written on your leaflet, but for those people who haven’t read it I enclose the leaflets next paragraph:#Following a detailed analysis of our pricing structure, Live Argyll are introducing a new low cost membership scheme.#In short, we’ve decided to shed some pounds. From st April your direct debit will be amended in line with the new pricing structure. Same fantastic facilities, at a much reduced cost.#What good news I thought as I rushed to open letter number two.This letter told me that from st April my we’s swimming concession membership would be increasing from £. to £. per month.This is a  per cent increase in charges, I then went back to letter one and read it again and it definitely said ‘at a much reduced cost’.I then slowly opened letter three wondering what it would be about.Possibly news that the car park was now ready for use after months of work, but alas no. It just gave details of when you would collect the new direct debit.I feel a  per cent increase in pensioners# swimming concessions is really excessive in the present climate.I also think that the department which writes your leaflets and your finance management should get together and try to explain to the public how they interpret the sentence #Same fantastic facilities, at a much reduced cost #.Next time the three letters should be in one envelope – it’s cheaper.Geoffrey BellKilkerran Cottage,Kilkerran Road,Campbeltown.

title: thought for the week march 15 2019
story: It made me wonder why someone would choose the period of Lent for that purpose. Why not give up something at any timeLent is irrelevant For centuries, Christians have chosen to deny themselves things they enjoy on their journey during Lent. This usually takes the form of chocolate or alcohol or whatever luxury would be sorely missed.It is a time of abstinence and is meant to focus attention on the spiritual journey as we walk the Easter road once again.However it is becoming more popular now to take something on, rather than give something up.People engage in ious activities from committing to write a letter to a prisoner of conscience every day via Amnesty International, to serving in a soup kitchen.There is much we can do in this world. A world in danger from climate change, war, abuse of power, and general disregard for the fragility of the planet.Online petitions flood into our mailboxes every day asking us to sign them for a multitude of worthy causes, and it is dficult to keep up with it all.However maybe we could make a decision this Lent to focus on one of these issues, and make a personal resolution to do something to help.As we think of Jesus taking on the power of the Roman army and the might of the establishment, we know that even one person can make a dference.Yes, that one person was Jesus. But didn#t he promise to send his spirit to be with us – to make a dference

title: letter arran ferry service plea
story: As chair of the Lochranza and Catacol Community Association on the Isle of Arran I have written to the chief executive of Transport Scotland.The association has asked him to revisit the recently rejected proposal for a Lochranza to Claonaig winter ferry service.The association firmly believes that the potential strategic benefits of piloting such a service would, given time, prove highly signicant.Businesses in Arran and Argyll, of all kinds, would benefit greatly, and the through Arran route would open up lines of communication, and closer ties in terms of tourism, transport and infrastructure.The perceived benefits would be felt on Arran, but more so, on the mainland, particularly in Kintyre and Argyll, which have much to gain from an enhanced all year service.It is worth mentioning that this service seems, in terms of weather and technical reliability, to have signicantly better resilience than the Brodick to Ardrossan service.Offering a year-round alternative means of getting on and off the island, particularly in unforeseen circumstances, is in the views of many, not only desirable, but essential.I have copied this letter to other interested parties including the first minister Nicola Sturgeon.Ken Thorburn,

title: calmacs lochranza bonanza
story: So it was on Monday when CalMac#s diesel-electric MV Catriona, one of the newest vessels in the fleet, was brought into service on the Cloanaig to Lochranza run.Its job, almost unbeliveably,  was to alleviate pressure at Ardrossan,  miles away, where a crash caused a smaller vessel to be operating.The super smooth, almost silent ferry, ran a continuous shuttle and judging by the midday sailing immediately became popular.Not everyone had driven round, for some Kintyre folk it offered an easy day out on Arran.A number of Islay and whisky tourists were able to include Lochranza Distillery on their itineraries.This begs the question: Why not upgrade the single-track B between Claonaig and Kennacraig to improve it for winter A year round Cloanaig to Lochranza service may reinvigorate trade between one of Arran#s iconic villages, Skipness, Tarbert, Kintyre and Islay.Springbank and Glen Scotia distilleries have found whisky tourists are not seasonal. The same will be true at Lochranza with an easy route open.

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: mid argyll photo club snaps up trophy
story: Leaving Campbeltown and Carradale trailing, Mid Argyll won the annual Frank Walton competition between all nine Argyll photo clubs for the first time in  years.Cowal and Mid Argyll both scored the same total points but Mid Argyll was declared the winner, having entered the highest scoring inidual image.The top image # scoring   # was In Safe hands Verina Litster’s photo of  baby Nia held by her father Derek Robertson who is a firefighter at Inveraray and Clydebank.Verina also scored joint second highest with Dreich Night in Glasgow, an image that she took on her mobile phone.Helen Phillip was joint rd with Café Le giving the club a st, nd and rd placing.See all MACC entries at  http:www.macc.ukphotographers -fwcomp.htmlOn Thursday evening, March , about fty amateur photographers from across Argyll and Bute braved the wild weather, many making a long detour to Arrochar due to the A being closed overnight at Inveraray.The competition was hosted this year by the Three Villages Camera Club in the Three Villages Hall in Arrochar.A record number of nine Argyll photo clubs entered this year, demonstrating the upsurge of enthusiasm for improving digital images through friendly competition for the Frank Walton Argyll Inter-club Trophy.The Bute Photographic Society was added to clubs in Campbeltown, Carradale, Cowal, Helensburgh, Mid-Argyll, Oban, Peninsulaand Three Villages.Each club submitted  images from each club to be judged by Neil McGregor of the Kirkintilloch Camera Club.Neil made useful comments on each of the  images, with encouraging suggestions for improvement rather than criticism.The trophy was donated in  by Frank Walton, the photographer who had the camera shop in Oban, and the last time Mid Argyll won the cup was back in  when it was a slide competition.The clubs take turns to organise the event in their home towns. The next competition will be held in Dunoon in March .Scores out of : Mid Argyll CC , Cowal CC , Peninsula CC  , Oban Photographic Club , Helensburgh Digital Photography Club , Campbeltown CC , Bute Photographic Society , Carradale CC , Three Villages CC .In Safe hands Verina Litster’s photo of baby Nia held by her father Derek Robertson who is a firefighter at Inveraray and Clydebank. title: book festivals new coordinator
story: Portnahaven-based Kirsty was chosen ahead of some strong competition for the new part-time post, and she will work closely with the festival committee to deliver the event from August  to September .This year’s event will be headlined by top crime writer Ian Rankin, with cookery writer and novelist Sue Lawrence, Mortal Engines author Philip Reeve, and high profile historian Tom Devine also attending.Committee chairwoman Isla Rosser Owen said: #We’ve been run entirely by volunteers up to now, but the festival has grown to a point where we needed to bring someone on board as our organisational linchpin.#With our schools programme and events across Islay and Jura, the festival takes a lot of organising, so we were delighted to find someone local with the right combination of skills, contacts and enthusiasm.#Kirsty is a legal studies graduate who worked as a paralegal on the mainland before coming home to Islay with husband Graham in .Kirsty said: #The last few years have been very child focused and I was looking for the right opportunity. When I saw the book festival advert I just thought, #That’s perfect, it combines my organisational side, my creative side and my love of books.# For something like this to come up on Islay is amazing.#Last year’s Islay Book Festival was the biggest yet. The committee is currently looking for sponsors for this year’s event and on a longer term basis to make the festival sustainable.Anyone or any business interested, can get in touch with Kirsty on hello@islaybookfestivalIniduals can support the festival through the JustGiving link on www.islaybookfestivalKirsty Izat joins the Islay Book Festival team. title: community shop stocks lifes essentials
story: Running out of milk or bread in Carradale and being faced with a -mile round trip is no joke.That has been the reality for East Kintyre residents since their village shop closed last August.It will all change from today at am, when, for a period, expected to be no more than two years, Carradale Community Trust , aided by  volunteers, will run a temporary shop in a £, Portakabin at the village hall car park.The community shop scheme has been made possible by with a £, donation from salmon farm company MOWI, a £, grant and a £, loan from the East Kintyre Windfarm Trust.CCT trustee David Prag said: #The idea is not to provide a shopping venue.#The rationale is thatyou run out of something it will not mean a -mile trip to Campbeltown.#We are a temporary essentials shop with one shelf of local produce such as Kintyre eggs.#It is possible for a community shop to work but it must be emphasised it is a temporary solution which will not be permanent.#The underlying word is temporary and the trust is not in this for financial gain.#It will disappear as soon as a shop opens in the village.#CCT is trying to establish a permanent shop which is why we are looking at this for a maximum of two years.#Hopefully by then some sort of decision will have been made about a permanent shop.#The shop will be open four hours a day, from am to pm, from Monday to Saturday and will only take cash with at least two members of staff on duty at any one time.There was a decision-making team of four, Margaret Richardson, Nudita Smithson, Jenn Lee and Lesley Prag. They applied for the grants and negotiated with the wholesaler as it was unlikely the shop would meet minimum order requirements.#In most villages the village shops are a leline, particularly during bad weather, for the elderly, those without transport and the vulnerable, said Mrs Prag, #Village shops provide a focal point, a place to meet, a communication hub and are the lynchpin of everyday le.#They help us recognise our neighbours and give us an opportunity to interact.#This, in turn, helps develop our sense of community, belonging, responsibility and safety.#Alan Milstead, also a CCT trustee, added: #Since the Carradale baker#s shop closed last August CCT has been working to get a wee shop opened to help all villagers live a little better.#The project has been supported by a majority of Carradale residents and will be in place for up to two years while a new village hub is established.#That will include a shop that will be rented to an entrepreneur.#A iety of locations were looked at after CCT was unable to purchase the old baker#s shop.#A leading contender was to use the old school at the Carradale Network Centre but restricted and dficult parking there resulted in the new shop being established at the village hall car park.#David Prag explains how to change a till roll. title: from our files march 29 2019
story: Carradale firefighter honouredCrew commander Robert Strang of Carradale Fire Station was presented with the fire service medal for  years# service and good conduct on Tuesday night.Robert was presented with the medal by Area Commander Paul Connolly, watched by his fellow Carradale firefighters and members of the Campbeltown team who also attended.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOSeal of approvalThe call of the wild called loudly for a seal pup released at a secret location in Argyll last week just over two months after being found on a Kintyre beach more dead than alive.The seal was found on a beach at Bellochantuy in January by local couple Robb Falconer and his we Judith.#He was all tangled in seaweed and I noticed his eyes were rolling,# said Mr Falconer.The Falconers made a stretcher from a plastic bag to move the pup off the beach.#He was very sickly and we were told that he wasn#t expected to live overnight,# said Mrs Falconer.Police at Campbeltown eventually took charge of the sickly pup and delivered him to a local vet.The pup, by now christened Titch, was eventually taken to Oban Seale Centre.Eventually Titch recovered and was fattened up enough for release into the wild. He swam off with hardly a glance back at the Falconers and staff from the seale centre on the beach.FIFTY YEARS AGOWho was at Windhoek A London man, who was a prisoner of war with a number of Campbeltown men during the Second World War, is trying to arrange a reunion with them this summer, when he will be touring Scotland.The man, Mr George Burnett, who served in the Rle Brigade, has written to the Provost of Campbeltown, Mr Dan McKinven, asking him for his assistance in tracing his wartime mates.He says that in August, , he was in a prisoner of war work camp at Windhoek, a small village in western Poland.In one room, where  men lived,  of them were from Campbeltown # #and a fine bunch of men they were#.Mr Burnett says that to the best of his knowledge they belonged to a TA anti-aircraft battery attached to the st Highland Division and they had been captured at St Valery.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOWorkers# memorable gatheringThe Campbeltown branch of the British Red Cross Society rounded off its years of war work with a social gathering, held in the Christian Institute last Friday night.There was a splendid representative gathering of workers and friends. The hall was pleasingly and appropriately decorated, and the tables were tastefully laid.Thefrom beginning to end was free and sociable, and the gathering made a memorable period to a succession of years of labour in which all who participated are entitled to take pride.Sherf Macmaster Campbell presided. The chairman, in opening the proceedings after tea, said they had come pretty near to the end of five of the most wonderful years in the history of this country in that it was good to be alive to attend a meeting like this.That night they looked back upon the stirring, cruel period through which they had passed with mixed feelings. They thought of the lives that had been sacriced, of the men who had been maimed for le, of the men who had been enfeebled for le, and on that account they all felt sad.

title: gutsy away performance as pupils share the spoils
story: Campbeltown Pupils SAFL Premier OneThe McFadyen sponsored Pupils FC collected their seventh draw of the current season.In a season which has seen the greatest number of games ending with shared points since the club entered the SAFL system in  .Nevertheless, over ninety minutes this was a gutsy away performance by the visitors, a team who have proved time and again that they will not be easily beaten.This is specially encouraging given the relative inexperience within the club’s emerging squad.The game opened in explosive fashion when the Pupils used the width of the pitch to create an opportunity for Bailey Freeman.The youngster’s well-judged parting volley found the net from yards # his first Pupils goal and only five minutes on the clock.Argyle, however: were in no mood to be passive, replying almost immediately.A fine cross from the right was headed home by ex-Haldane striker, Ross Davies, a man with a history of causing problems for unsuspecting defences.The Pupils regained the lead midway through the first half.A fine through ball allowed Sary Rahma to outpace the home defence and score with a low drive beyond the advancing goalkeeper # a typical goal from the Pupils jet-paced front man.However, the visitors failed to learn from earlier lessons, and were punished in similar fashion when centre forward, Davies, scored once more with a towering header to bring the scores level at half time.Discussions at the break must have involved attention to marking at the cross ball, as the visitors appeared to be more comfortable in the second period against the home side’s tall front runners.Nevertheless, a change in tactics saw Argyle grab the lead early in the second period, a through ball exposing Pupil’s goalkeeper, Alastair Ferguson, to a one-on-one situation with striker Thomas Kelly who scored with ease.For a short time, the visitors stood firm during the home side’s best spell of the match, and showed their mettle by bouncing back with an equalising goal in the th minute.A speculative effort, inside the box, from Sary Rahma was parried by the home keeper, but only into the path of the incoming Ryan Deans who brought the scores level # a fine strike from an in-form player.It was all to play for, and the Pupils could have won in the closing stages when Keith Mitchell weaved his way into the penalty box, only to be chopped from behind.The player tried to retain his balance, but eventually tumbled to the ground.In the games only controversial moment, the referee allowed play to continue for advantage.The game ended in a hard fought, but for both sides, probably a fair share of the points.Campbeltown Pupils travel to Kings Park Rangers tomorrow.

Violet also won the two-lap race, shot putt and both the long and triple jumps.Runner-up Evie Kellett from Salen won the speed bounce and Ruby Jo Phillips from Lochgilphead won the high jump.Jamie MacIntyre from Rockfield won the javelin and both the long and triple jumps to secure the under-sevens title ahead of two girls from Castlehill, Emma Johnston and Eleyna McEachran.Eleyna dominated in the running events with her winning time of . seconds in the four-lap race, only a fth of a second off the age record.There was an entry of more than  young athletes at the Argyll final of Sports Hall Athletics, held at Atlantis Leisure in Oban.The final was the last in a series of five competitions held in Argyll over the winter months, promoted by Mid Argyll Athletic Club.After more than four hours of intense competition, four Argyll age records were broken and one equalled.The top performance of the day in the boys events was by Donald Campbell from Rockfield primary, Oban, who was the under-nine champion, winning all seven events with some style.James Muir from Rockfield was the under- champion, ahead of Jack Green from Dalintober who won the triple jump.Jacques Coates from Park primary, Oban, won the under- contest, with Oliver Reid from Campbeltown the runner-up.In the boys# under-sevens, Charley Gilchrist from Dalintober was third overall thanks to a win in the triple jump.The organisers thanked all competitors and said special thanks are due to the families from Mull and Kintyre for making the long journey to Oban.For full results and more athletics news, turn to pages  and .Argyll Athletics winners. _t_Athletics Photo by David McPhee Oban Times

title: letter ken butters spreads memories
story: I enjoyed reading Down Memory Lane in the March  edition of the Courier re Ken Butters.Although I don#t really keep up with social media I know Ken from other sources but there were a couple of things that I didn#t remember.Ken said he lived at number three Hillside road, I was at number four, his photograph at the prefab was interesting as I have one very similar of me just next door.Ken also mentioned his grandmother#s flat above McIlchere#s bakery on Main Street, I remember being in the flat as a schoolboy with Ken.I feel sure it was indeed above McIlchere#s shop but not on Main Street, I think it was on the corner of Longrow and Saddell Street, down a bit from the County garage but I may be mistaken.Ken and I used to go to the cubs together and swap comics on our . I don#t know how I remember all this as it was more than  years ago.Ken and I didn#t keep in touch after his family emigrated but did meet up more than  years later.I wonderany of your readers noticed the square and compass on Ken#s kilt pin Ken#s mother Belle was in Campbeltown, I think around  and happened to be visiting a friend who, at the time, was a colleague of my we at Campbeltown Hospital.I talked to Belle and she remembered me but I didn#t remember her, I said I could only wait a little while as I was on my way to the masonic lodge.She remarked that Ken was a member of the lodge in Cornwall Ontario and passed on my details, this was before the digital age and we exchanged a couple of snail mails.Ken visited Campbeltown with his we Judy in , we met up and I took him into the lodge where he took several photographs. One of which I believe was shown in the Old Campbeltown pages Facebook featuring yours truly.It was amazing to see Ken#s photo in the Courier, thanks for the memories.PS I must get into this social media thingy though I have e:mailed Ken regarding the story.Ron Gay,Dunoon.
