title: Rosemary Goring  Time to stand up to the tyranny of the mobile phone
story: Glenalmond imposed a ban on mobiles during the academic day in September. Six months on, teachers detect an increase in concentration during class and greatly enhanced sociability in break-time. As one of the schoolrsquos sub-wardens remarked: ldquoBefore the ban you could walk into a room in total silence, because everyone was glued to their phones. It became a pleasure to walk into the dining room at lunch time and see  pupils actually talking to one another rather than staring at their screens. Kilgraston, a private school for girls in Bridge of Earn, recently implemented the same policy, with similar findings.: Agenda: Pupils need balance of screen time and healthy activityTherersquos no doubt that, in terms of inidual happiness, the new-found willingness to chat and make friends is what matters most. Whether or not a sharper focus during school hours will translate into better exam results is yet to be seen, but you donrsquot need to be a psephologist to predict the likelihood of a direct correlation.The effect of a clamorous phone on young peoplersquos prospects is probably the subject of a hundred half-written PhDs. Across Europe and North America, teachers and lecturers are inventively trying to mitigate the attritional effect these devices might be having on studentsrsquo attention spans.At a formative age, exam grades and social skills are the foundation on which the rest of a le is built. This is not to say itrsquos impossible to retake exams, or learn belatedly how to hold a conversation, but the earlier these stepping stones are crossed the better.Itrsquoll be fascinating to see what comes of Glenalmondrsquos initiative. In the meantime, I canrsquot help thinking itrsquos not just in schools that locking up devices would be beneficial, and not only the young who need weaning or protecting. The compulsive desire constantly to check for missed calls, texts, social media, games, music or whatever  this seductively pocket-sized companion can offer is an addiction.Adults are every bit as much in thrall as younger generations, fingers twitching like a chain smokerrsquos in search of a fag whenever their device is beyond reach. Studies on our use of phones show an alarming frequency of touching, swiping and scrolling: around  times a day according to some .Touching them has become an uncontrollable reflex that interrupts even the most serious occasions. Bad enough a phone ringing from the casket as it rolls into the furnace, but how much worse when itrsquos grieving attenders who cannot get through the funeral without a quick check on the football results or snapchat. Who didnrsquot laugh to hear John Bercow, Speaker of the House of Commons, chastise Andrea Leadsom and one of her colleagues for ldquofiddling with their phones during a Commons debate last week  Even in far less exalted offices Irsquove seen executives ostentatiously sneak a look during high-powered meetings.Those who then leave the room to take a call are effectively demonstrating that they are king of the jungle, whereas subordinates must wait until the session is ended.In the space of two decades, mobiles have infiltrated all but our sleeping hours. Irsquove lost count of the talks Irsquove attended where some in the audience have skimmed messages or Googled within plain sight of the speaker. When yoursquore the one giving the speech, seeing a face uplit by a screen is only marginally less distracting than a person snoring in the front row.Catching somebody tweeting, which some event organisers actively promote, can also be seriously off-putting. Not as irritating, though, as when my husband attended a court case, where his fellow journalists were tweeting every few minutes.Whenever they did so, they then asked him to fill them in on what the accused or witnesses or judge had said while their attention was distracted.The issue is not the importance of our phones, but one of control. We should be in charge of them, rather than the other way round. Yet something in these devices panders to a universal need for stimulus and novelty, for any excuse not to think deeply for very long also, to the primitive fear of being left out.As a result, these bits of plastic become our masters, demanding unswerving loyalty. In a way that would have been inconceivable in George Orwellrsquos or Ray Bradburyrsquos day, this tiny tyrant holds the power to connect us to the rest of the world. If left unattended it threatens to strand us on an island called lonely, or boring, or too old.Irsquom waiting for the day when we see the Queen step onto a podium to cut a ribbon, and tuck away her phone before reaching for the scissors. When that hour arrives, wersquoll know for certain that we have lost our struggle against the march of the machines.

title: herald-diary-alex-mcleish-in-full-on-bond-mode
story: OUR sports pages reported that Scotland boss Alex McLeish is on the verge of being sacked. Always had a good sense of humour Alex. When he was presenting an award to Glasgow nightclub owner James Mortimer, Alex noted that the theme that evening was James Bond and reminded the audience that the advertising slogan for The Man with the Golden Gun was, "One shot cost a million dollars." Added Alex: "I signed a few like that."My memory also recalls Alex, in a black suit, being interviewed by the BBCs Chick Young, also in a black suit, outside an office in Park Circus. As they were chatting, a couple of punters came up the stairs, and trying to be helpful Alex told them: "Lads, its no a pub." Assuming Alex was a bouncer they protested: "Are you no letting us in " We can see the imposing McLeish as a doorman, but quite how they imagined the diminutive Chick in such a roleis harder to fathom.Moving speechMOTHERS Day this Sunday, so get those flowers bought. As one mother remarked the other day: "My -year-old daughter has texted to ask me what I wanted for Mothers Day. Would it be bad form to reply with, For you and your boyfriend to move out "Give us a breakSORRY, cant ignore Brexit. Reader John Henderson points us towards the German paper Die Zeit which imagined it as a TV series and declared: "Yesterdayrsquos twist was the best yet: first the unloved PM offers to go, then MPs seize the initiative and it seems the tide may be turning. But wait... In the end, it turns out they can agree on ndash absolutely nothing. So, cue uproar in the House, and the credits start running. lsquoOrder,rsquo roars John Bercow. Please do not adjust your set: wersquoll be back right after the break.Mums the wordAT a slight tangent, Sofie Hagen states: "My friend sent me a photo of her with Theresa May. I thought this was very weird. They looked so happy together. I said, lsquoI canrsquot believe you could smile standing next to such an evil woman.rsquo Anyway, long story short, it was her mother."And a reader emails: "After two years of Trump making their nation the laughing stock of the world, Americans can finally breathe a sigh of relief. The countdown to Prime Minister Boris Johnson has begun."Took it on chinGROWING old, continued. Says a reader in Rutherglen: "I have reached the age where I tried to flick something white which had caught in my beard, but it didnt move. Turns out my beard is turning white."Winning waysA GLASGOW reader swears to us he heard a woman on his bus into town tell her pal: "My husband would win gold in the Lazy Olympics ndashhe could ever bother getting off his backside to enter them."Roll with itOUR readers reminiscing about the Dennistoun Palais include Brian Logan who says: "I used to go to the Dennistoun Palais in the sixties after it became Rollarena. I remember flying round the floor on roller skates to the sound of Englebert Humperdinck, Tom Jones and The Monkees. Then Irsquod cross Duke Street to the Rendezvous Cafe which sold possibly the best ice cream on the planet. It fair takes me back."Growing problemSTILL, at least the weather is getting a bit better, but even there folk are having problems. As Justin Staggs put it: "Youre not going to believe this, but at some point over the winter someone broke into my house and swapped all my spring clothes with slightly smaller, tighter replicas."

title: from-scotch-and-wry-to-jack-and-victor-whats-the-best-scots-comedy-of-all-time
story: Not bad for a show about two old boys that began le when a viral hit was a dose of the flu and social media was borrowing someonersquos paper in the pub.Like so many Scottish comedy hits, Still Game followed the rules of the sitcom format while cheekily subverting them. In this case, Jack and Victor were widowed pensioners, pootling around with their pals. Just like the gang in Last of the Summer Wine, but no-one would ever confuse the two. Still Game was punk to Summer Winersquos Donny Osmond: spiky, ahead of the game, uniquely Scottish in its outlook and taste for tragi-comedy. Oh, and it was ******* fond of swearing.:TV REVIEW: Did Still Game go out with a bang or a whimper The mix of light and shade was evident from the opening episode, now available on Netflix. ldquoFlittinrsquo starts with a cosy scene of an elderly chap, Jack Ford Kiernan, co-creator with Greg Hemphill gardening. Then the woman next door bursts into the street threatening to batter her husband, and the neighbour upstairs flicks his fag into the pensionerrsquos attempt at Eden. All Scottish le, as it is lived in certain parts, is here. Goodness and decency versus what a police comedy to come would call ldquothe bams.It is a world away from The One OrsquoClock Gang, many peoplersquos first taste of Scottish television comedy. Running on Scottish Television and starring Dorothy Paul, Jimmy Nairn, Larry Marshall and Charlie Sim, the s sketch and song show could be politely described as patchy.From there any tour of Scottish comedy would take in The Vital Spark, Francie and Josie, Stanley Baxter, Scotch and Wry, Naked Video, Rab C Nesbitt, and on to Chewinrsquo the Fat, where Kiernan and Hemphill displayed their talents, finally arriving at Still Game.The show ran from - before Kiernan and Hemphill decided they had had enough, much to the shock of the BBC. As former BBC Scotland commissioner Ewan Angus told The Moments That Made Ford and Greg, a documentary shown last night: ldquoGenerally speaking, people do not walk away from successful shows, and do not walk away with a definite commission for a six-part series.Billy Connollys Ultimate World TourBut saunter away they did, ing in triumph in  with a record-shattering run of , sold out, live shows at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow.With the appetite clearly there for another show, the BBC came calling again and the shows met with initial success. By the eighth series, however, the comedy was starting to feel tired, the gentle patter and daft gags far outweighed by swearing, crudeness and slapstick.In truth, Scottish comedy had moved on. The age of Chewinrsquo the Fat had become the Iannucci era. Young comedians wanted to do things their own way, in keeping with the times. Kevin Bridges sold out the SSE Hydro, having made his name on TV, not in a sitcom but in  shows. Then there was the arrival of Netflix and other streaming services, bringing the best of world comedy to your TV set, tablet or smartphone.Still Game has a fixed place in Scotlandrsquos affections, says Dr Andy Dougan, lecturer in film and television studies at The Royal Conservatoire of Scotland.:Cast say emotional goodbyes as Still Game airs final episodeldquoIt has managed to become that rarest of things, a national treasure. It is regarded with a fondness that has little to do with how funny it actually is.ldquoI donrsquot think it is as good or as groundbreaking as the show that spawned it, Chewinrsquo the Fat. Also, and this may be a generational thing, it is not as good as say Naked Video or Rab C. Nesbitt. These were shows that said something important about the culture in which they were broadcast which Still Game doesnrsquot really do.Still Game is perhaps best seen as the bridge between old Scots comedy and new, between traditional sitcoms and todayrsquos edgier offerings. With nine series to its name, two more than Only Fools and Horses, it stands comparison with the best of them. Wherever the road goes next for comedy, and for Kiernan and Hemphill, there will always be a drink behind the bar for Still Game.

title: analysis-power-to-the-people-but-it-has-to-be-processed-through-parliament
story: The happy spectacle came as MPs seized control of the parliamentary agenda and the political classes continued to battle their way through the tortuous never-ending Brexit process.Today, there will be yet another episode of the political reality show.Theresa May will seek to get round MPs rejecting her deal for a third time by splitting the process in two first the Withdrawal Agreement bit about the orce process and then, later, the Political Declaration bit about the UKrsquos future relationship with the EU.It is a somewhat crude attempt to buy time as the EUrsquos offer was for Parliament to pass the Withdrawal Agreement this week to get the May  extension. Once  that is done, then the Government would come back to pass part two in a third meaningful vote. Good luck.However, the level of opposition outrage at the Prime Ministerrsquos latest political contortion from the likes of Labour and the SNP, not to mention the Toriesrsquo supposed parliamentary partners, the DUP, suggests it could well fail.A number of indignant MPs accused the Tory Government of skulduggery and suggested its move could even prove to be illegal. But the stentorian Attorney General Geoffrey Cox assured MPs that Mrs Mayrsquos strategy was ldquoperfectly reasonable andhellip perfectly lawful".Perhaps Julian Lewis, the senior Conservative backbencher, spoke for many when he said MPs had been left "in tears" at the prospect of "yet again" being asked to vote on the same proposals when they had "twice taken the dficult decision to vote against a three-line whip".If the Government fails today, then the focus willto Parliamentrsquos attempt to find a centre of Brexit gravity on Monday with another look at the alternatives.The customs union is favourite but, given Mrs May is staunchly opposed to it as it goes against the Tory manesto, then we could end up in another Brexican stand-off between Government and Parliament.Such is the level of daily confusion and uncertainty swilling around the corridors of Westminster, MPs have become accustomed to living day by day, trying to comprehend the ins and outs of the latest development and not knowing quite how events will unfold tomorrow.Today, a large pro-Brexit demonstration is expected outside the House of Commons.The word ldquobetrayal will be on many protestersrsquo lips given that March  was supposed to be ldquoindependence day. But now, of course, Brexit could happen on April  or May  or at some point in the distant future or not at all.Sadly, the Brexit process has coarsened the political debate, fuelled often by the rages and rants on social media.The people have spoken, voters insist, so why cannot politicians just get on with it and implement their will  Simples, as Mrs May, might say.But, of course, the torment that ministers and MPs are going through on a daily basis underlines how this is far from a straightforward exercise.The  vote produced a clear proposition: the UK should leave the EU. Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary, has argued how Parliament transferred its sovereignty to the people on EU membership and so should now comply with their instruction.But the reality is in a representative democracy sovereignty always lies with Parliament.Edmund Burke, the th century philosopher, famously argued that those elected were trustees not delegates.ldquoYour representative owes you, not his industry only but his judgement and he betrays, instead of serving you,he sacrices it to your opinion."The way our democracy works is that it flows through Parliament. Eventhere is a referendum, the decision has to be processed by MPs and peers.If for whatever reason they cannot, the only option, ultimately, is to put it back to the people for another decision which will once again have to be processed by Parliament. Hopefully, successfully the second time round.If voters do not like what MPs do or say, they have the power, every five years in a general election, to kick them out and elect someone they think will do and say what they want.Mr Burke was, to say the least, highly sceptical about the merits of democracy. As fate would have it after he expounded his controversial beliefs on what representative government meant in , voters - however few of them there were at the time - exercised their right and kicked him out. QED.

title: theresa-may-accused-of-trickery-as-half-of-brexit-deal-put-to-vote
story: The Prime Ministerrsquos tactical ldquowheeze to win a vote on just one half of the UK-EU deal ndash the Withdrawal Agreement or the orce part of the agreement - faces a high wall of resistance as Labour branded it the ldquoblindest of blind Brexits and the SNP and DUP pledged to oppose it too.During First Ministerrsquos Questions, Nicola Sturgeon told MSPs the whole Brexit process was now, thanks to the Tories, a ldquocomplete and utter mess and insisted stopping it altogether ldquomust now be our top priority and moreover that is now possible".She mocked the PM, noting: "Theresa May must be the only leader in living memory who has tried to fall on her own sword and has managed to miss."But Donald Trump, addressing reporters outside the White House, came to her defence, describing Mrs May as ldquostrong, tough and shersquos in there fighting.The US President added: "Shes a very nice lady. Shes a friend of mine. I hope she does well. I hope the Brexit movement and everything happening there goes very well.Todayrsquos latest Commons debate and vote on Britainrsquos departure from the EU will take place as outside Parliament pro-Brexit campaigners stage a mass protest at the delay to coincide with the original exit day of March .The Governmentrsquos attempt to pass just the first part of the deal is a bid to buy time.The EU offer to grant an extension to May  is specically conditional on MPs passing the ldquoWithdrawal Agreement this week.The Government hopes thatit is successful, then it can use the next eight weeks or so to win support for the second half the Political Declaration on the future relationship with the EU.If it fails, then the extension only runs for the next two weeks until April .On Monday, MPs will again take control of the parliamentary agenda to try to find consensus around an alternative plan.Under the  EU Withdrawal Act, Brexit can only happenMPs approve both the Withdrawal Agreement and the Political Declaration together.But the Government suggestedMPs approved the first part of the deal, then it would bring forward a Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which could be rewritten to obviate the need for a third meaningful vote. Any detailed discussions on the future relationship could then take place after Brexit happened.However, the chances of Mrs May getting the Withdrawal Agreement through appear slim given it contains the controversial Irish backstop customs arrangement, which continues to represent the biggest obstacle to support from Northern Irelandrsquos Democratic Unionists and Brexit-backing Tories in the anti-EU European Research Group.In a -minute phonecall with the PM yesterday, Jeremy Corbyn confirmed Labour MPs would not back the Government move.A party spokesman said: "He made clear Labour will not agree a blindfold Brexit to force through Theresa Mays damaging deal, which would leave the next Tory Party leader free to rip up essential rights and protections and undermine jobs and living standards."Mrs Mayrsquos dramatic offer to resign on Wednesday night to enable a successor to take over the second part of the Brexit process in negotiating the future UK-EU relationship had limited success. While some Tory Brexiteers swung behind her plan as the ldquoleast worst option, others did not.And the DUP reaffirmed its own opposition to it as it would carve out Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK by putting a regulatory border down the Irish Sea.After John Bercow, the Commons Speaker, made clear the Government could not bring back a substantially unchanged Brexit plan - given it had been heavily rejected twice - ministers and officials had to scratch their heads to find a way to present it again.Having a debate and vote on just the Withdrawal Agreement was ruled in order by Mr Bercow and Andrea Leadsom, the Commons Leader, urged all MPs to ldquosupport it and ensure that we leave the EU on May , giving people and businesses the certainty they need".But the Governmentrsquos highly unusual move sparked an outcry on opposition benches.Labourrsquos Valerie Vaz accused UK ministers of treating MPs in an ldquoabsolutely disgraceful way, which underlined their disrespect for Parliament."This is the Government playing games, declared the Shadow Leader. ldquoParliament, our constituents, future trading partners and the country will not countenance this."Ben Bradshaw, the former Labour Cabinet Minister, warned the Government against using ldquomore attempted trickery or potentially illegal trickery by separating out the Withdrawal Agreement from the Political Declaration.His Labour colleague, Mary Creagh told MPs: "This is an extraordinary and unprecedented reverse ferret of the commitments that have been given by ministers to this place...that we should have our say on both items together."And is it not extraordinary that we have this coming right on the day when we know there are going to be far-right demonstrators gathering in Parliament Square " asked the Yorkshire MP.The SNPrsquos Pete Wishart was scathing, insisting Westminsterrsquos processes over Brexit were in an ldquoabsolute guddle.He explained: ldquoIt has almost got to the point in this House where it is so broken and the debate is so corrupted that we are now having debates through Points of Order. I can barely imagine that we have reached that stage just now it demonstrates how badly broken things are.The Nationalistsrsquo Shadow Leader added todayrsquos sitting was ldquoall about the Governmentrsquos latest wheeze to get their doomed Brexit deal through.He added: ldquoThey are inviting us to consider the Withdrawal Agreement without the Political Declaration attached. It is a meaningful vote but it is a sort of Schroumldingerrsquos meaningful vote it is both alive and dead at the same time.Labourrsquos Chris Bryant described todayrsquos vote as a ldquomeaningless one and warned the Government: ldquoThe one precedent Im absolutely sure the House always abided by in the past and will abide by probably tomorrow is when the Government comes up with a policy, a change of mood, change of style, a dferent way of doing business which is too clever by half, it always loses."Ms Vaz also warned the Government motion could risk seeing the law "being broken" as it did not meet the requirements of the  European Union Withdrawal Act.But Geoffrey Cox, the Attorney General, sought to reassure MPs, saying: "When the House listens to the rationale behind it, when it hears the full context of it, Im sure the House will accept it is not only perfectly lawful, perfectly sensible and is designed to give this House an opportunity of availing itself of a right the European Union has given to us to avail ourselves of an extension until May ."The view of the Government is simply we could not let the time limit expire at pm tomorrow of allowing this House the opportunity of availing itself of that right. It is perfectly reasonable and it is perfectly lawful," he insisted.Sir Edward Leigh, the former Conservative minister, said his colleague Sir Oliver Letwin, the architect behind the process of so-called ldquoindicative votes, would take control on Monday to pursue Brexit deal alternativesthe Withdrawal Agreement were not approved before then."There is nothing to stop him now under our procedures from whittling down the options to one option, which almost certainly given the results last night would be permanent membership of the customs union."There is nothing to stop him putting this in a Bill, there is nothing stopping him making that an Act of Parliament and then the choice will be between - and I say this to my colleagues - permanent membership of the customs union or a general election," added the Lincolnshire MP.Mrs Leadsom replied: "I certainly feel this House needs to agree to fulfil on the  referendum and the Prime Ministers deal offers the means by which to deliver on that referendum but at the same time for those, who dont want to leave the European Union, to offer the closest economic and security partnership, it is a compromise and I do urge colleagues right across the House to back it."At Holyrood, the FM clashed with Jackson Carlaw, the interim Scottish Conservative leader, over the issue.Ms Sturgeon declared: "This whole process thanks to the Tories is now such a mess that stopping Brexit altogether must now be our top priority.There was criticism of SNP MPs, who voted against the proposal for the UK to have a customs union with the EU despite the party having long argued in favour of a soft Brexit, which would mean the UK staying within both this and the European single market.Mr Carlaw accused the Nationalist leader of attempting to stock up "faux outrage, grievance" on her "single-minded obsession" of independence."When it came to the crunch the First Minister whipped her MPs against supporting her own policy of a customs union," declared the Eastwood MSP."Isnt it the case that what Scotland saw yet again yesterday is then when push comes to shove for the SNP it is not about finding a solution to Brexit it is about pursuing their independence obsession."But Ms Sturgeon hit back, saying: "For two long years when stopping Brexit didnt seem possible the SNP argued for single market customs union membership compromise that was ignored by the Tories and indeed everybody .In other developments -*Speaking at the British Chambers of Commerce conference, David Lidington, Mays de facto deputy, pleaded with MPs to back the Brexit deal, saying: ldquoPoliticians of all political parties have a duty to put the national interest first so that we can put this controversy behind us and move on to a bright future for the British people."*Boris Johnson, who indicated he would back the PMrsquos deal following her resignation announcement, has reportedly told friends: ldquoItrsquos dead anyway.*A poll suggested Brexit was now the most important issue for Scots when consideringthe nation should be independent. Some  per cent cited this as the key one ahead of  per cent who regarded the economy as the most pressing factor.*Mark Francois, vice-chairman of the European Research Group of Tory Brexiteers, told BBC TV: ldquoI told my whip the other day I wouldnrsquot vote for itthey put a shotgun in my mouth.*Another Conservative Brexiteer Andrew Bridgen argued parliamentary arithmetic meant the PMrsquos deal stood no chance, saying: ldquoTwenty Conservatives and the DUP are not going to vote for it. It is not going to go through.*The SNPrsquos Neil Gray said the Governmentrsquos failure to replace Sarah Newton, who quit a fortnight ago as Disabilities Minister over Brexit, was a "shameful indictment" of the Tory administration and was evidence that it was ldquoconsumed by it.*MPs will on Monday afternoon debate the online petition - signed by nearly  million people - calling for Brexit to be scrapped.

title: the-tories-should-end-their-misery-and-finally-split-apart
story: Just as she had previously reassured backbench Tory MPs that she wouldnrsquot be leader by the time of the next General Election , shersquos promising that shersquoll quither catastrophically bad Withdrawal Agreementis passed. This is like a persistent insurance salesman offering to sell you cover after hersquos soaked your soft furnishings in petrol and then offering to leave quietlyyoursquoll just let him fling a lit box of Swan Vestas onto the sofa ndash and later discovering that the policy specically excludes arson.:Ian McConnell: At least EU, unlike strident Mrs May, has time for Remainers on BrexitWhether the Prime Minister can come up with a iation, or a decoupling, or some other twist that will persuade the Speaker to allow her to table Meaningful Vote : Westminster Drt, today is largely irrelevant. Unless the Democratic Unionist Partycan be won round, there seems no chance it will pass, even with the very attractive sweetener of seeing the back of her. And why should it  Wednesdayrsquos votes on eight dferent options , showed that five of the eight were more popular than the deal Mrs May is still flogging, like some specialist purveyor of hippic euthanasia.Since none of those hypothetical options secured a majority, we neednrsquot worry about their qualities, nor about the small detail of whether they would be acceptable to the EU. All the same, it says something about the obtuseness of MPs that the order of their preferences was more or less the opposite of the relative merits of each plan, and probably of popular opinion.It would be tempting, and satisfying, to lay the blame for this on the stupidity, cowardice and lack of principle that characterises the Parliamentary Conservative Party. There ought to be a new measure of political debasementto describe MPs who, out of nothing but naked personal ambition, now say that they might be prepared to back the WA after all.But the ghastliness of Tory MPs is matched, perhaps even superseded, by the abysmal quality of Opposition MPs. They have almost universally seen Brexit not as a liberation, an opportunity, a challenge, a problem, or a danger ndash or any of the other things you might choose to see it as ndash for the country but, instead, as an opportunity to promote their own, or their partyrsquos, fortunes. The view of Jeremy Corbyn and his clique is clearly that theyrsquod like Mrs Mayrsquos deal to go through, and then prove a disaster, so that he stands a chance of getting elected. This ignores the fact that the only reason Mrs May is still in her job, with approval ratings of minus is that the Labour leaderrsquos rating is minus . The view of most Labour MPs seems to be that theyrsquod like to revoke it, while a scant majority of Labour voters wantto see it implemented.The SNP, naturally, views the debate solely in terms of what it might mean for the prospects for independence, cheerfully picking and choosing from contradictory arguments about the will of the people, the necessity of abiding by referendum results and the dficulty of unpicking years of shared laws, regulation, industry and economic policy from political unions, as long as it suits their agenda.What the Liberal Democrats, who ought to be polling at least  per cent, are doing, I have no idea. Except that Sir Vince Cable seems to have anticipated Mrs Mayrsquos novel policy of announcing a resignation but nonetheless staying in the job, getting in everyonersquos way. The DUP seems to see the current chaos as a nice little earner.But with the imminentresignation of Mrs May, it is naturally the Conservative party that is getting attention. Yet the Prime Ministerrsquos departure is what logicians would describe as necessary but not sufficient. If shersquos only going to goshe gets her deal through, wersquod have a new PM shackled by a deal which he or she didnrsquot devise, and probably detests ndash we know that because everybody except Mrs May detests it. For the Tory party there are the additional dficulties of finding a new leader who fulfills all the following criteria: pro-Brexit capable of sorting out a dogrsquos dinner not totally discredited already and stands some chance of winning a general election.:Patrick Harvie: Disrespect shown to Scotland is reason enough to push for independenceA lot of party members would also like the candidate to be a Tory, since all the non-Brexit policies introduced by the Government have been profoundly unConservative unsurprisingly, since the manesto on which they ran the last time wasthe most Left-wing since .You may, like so many people, have no sympathy with the Tories. Indeed, even those well-disposed towards the party have no reason to approve of the current shower, given their demonstrable failure to do any of the things that are supposed to be the Conservativesrsquo long suit safeguarding the national interest, competently administering the economy, resisting useless and bossy legislation and so on. Since they are more ided than at any time since the arguments over the repeal of the Corn Laws, no civic-minded person should have any interest in keeping the party together better for them, and us, to end their misery.: Alison Rowat: Shame on the Tories for putting party before countryYet there remains the horrying reality ndash as there is with the multitudinous Brexit options ndash that every other outcome looks even worse. We were supposed to be leaving the EU at  orsquoclock tonight in an orderly and friendly fashion, with everyone knowing exactly where we stood. Instead, Mrs Mayrsquos legacy is that we donrsquot know who will be prime minister tomorrow, or what lies in store for the country or for public discourse, which is more sharply ided than at any time in centuries. I may have understated how bad she is.

title: glasgow-teenager-helps-uncover-gravestones-from-middle-ages-in-archaeology-dig-at-govan-church
story: Mark McGettigan volunteered to help the Stones and Bones dig at Govan Old Parish Church and found what turned out to be the first of three lost medieval sculptured stones.The -year-old, who signed up to take part with his mother Sandra, was helping with the survey of the area and felt something solid below the surface.: Cast say emotional goodbyes as Still Game airs final episodeHis discovery turned out to be part of the Govan Stones collection, dating back to the th or th century, featuring crosses and Celtic interlace designs.The S pupil from Lourdes Secondary School said: ldquoI was just prodding the ground to seethere was anything there and suddenly it made a noise and I realised I had hit something.ldquoMyself and two of the archaeologists worked out the area of the object and started to dig it out and clean it.ldquoI wasnrsquot too sure at the start what it was. But then we checked with the records and we realised it was one of the lost Govan Stones.ldquoI am extremely happy, in fact Irsquom ecstatic at what I helped to uncover.During the th century  stones were found in the graveyard with  of them taken into the church for safe keeping.The remaining stones were displayed against the wall of the churchyard by the Harland and Wolff shipyard which was demolished in  ndash leading experts to believe the stones were also destroyed.It is believed many of the stones survived, including the ones found in the community dig.Professor Stephen Driscoll is the University of Glasgowrsquos Professor of Historical Archaeology and part of The Govan Heritage Trust, which owns Govan Old Parish Church and the Govan Stones.:School strikes off as teachers accept % pay riseHe called it ldquothe most exciting discovery we have had at Govan in the last  years, adding: ldquoThe Govan Stones are a collection of international importance and these recovered stones reinforce the case for regarding Govan as a major early medieval centre of power.ldquoThe discovery is very timely because the Govan Heritage Trust is embarking on a major refurbishment of Govan Old, which will culminate in a redisplay of the collection.ldquoIn the coming months we look forward to continuing this community archaeological work to locate the other lost stones to assess their condition from a conservation perspective and to consider how best to secure their long-term future.Ingrid Shearer, of Northlight Heritage, also said: ldquoWersquore delighted that our volunteers have had the opportunity to make such a signicant discovery.ldquoTheyrsquove toughed it out through rain and snow over the past few weeks and their hard work and commitment has really paid off.ldquoGovan Old is the oldest churchyard in Scotland and we hope that this find will give a boost to plans for the future.

title: learn-about-the-benefits-of-a-fairview-beaconhurst-education
story: One week on from theirfirst Open Day, the school would like to thankthe families who attended and made the event an absolute success with your warm welcome and support. Staffare encouraged by the trust and confidence in the school, and the belief in our vision Education for a Better World.Fairview Beaconhurst will initially welcome students from Primary  to Senior with the rest of the Senior School set to open in August .Fairview Beaconhurst will host its next Open Day at the school on April  and  with mock lessons available to register for. Furthermore, Fairviewrsquos scores have consistently been above the world average especially in chemistry, physics, biology, business and visual arts.In Fairview Beaconhurst, traditional subject disciplines are used as a springboard for exploring multiple subjects from a new perspective.For example, many  or  year olds will first hear the fable of The Three Little Pigs in the context of an English lesson. In Fairview, the morals of the story are only the beginning of a journey that will encompass subjects as erse as English and Art through to Maths and Science.A central idea theme would be lsquothe properties of materials determine how people use themrsquo. From the start, students are challenged to go beyond the confines of the fable and observe and investigate the physical world around them to compare and contrast dferent materials and their properties, relate the fable to a real world context, and reach their own conclusion as to the choice of material for their lsquohousersquo.Building a scale model of the house from their material of choice combines both Maths and Art in a single lesson. Will this model house then survive against real weather conditions when it is tested outside  How will it compare to their colleagues efforts  By observing the successes and failures of the class as a whole, each inidual child gains a true appreciation of their learning through their reflection of the lessons and its connection to the real world in the context of the construction industry.

title: independent-group-applies-to-become-new-party-in-case-of-eu-poll
story: The Electoral Commission published a notice confirming ldquoChange UK - The Independent Group had applied to register as a party across the whole UK.Former Conservative Heidi Allen has been selected as interim leader.The group said it was looking for a "substantial number of MEP candidates with backgrounds from outside of politics.MPs are forbidden from also becoming MEPs, so it is unlikely any of the original TIG members would stand for Brussels.The fledgling party, based around eight former Labour and three former Tory MPs, could face its first national electoral test in less than two months.If MPs fail to pass Theresa Mayrsquos withdrawal agreement deal today, it could lead to a long delay to Brexit and the UK taking part in EU elections on May .As European elections in the UK are held under a list system, Change UK candidates could get elected with around  per cent of the vote.In a statement, the group said it was registering with that contest in mind.Ms Allen said: ldquoToday marks a huge step forward on The Independent Groups journey to becoming a fully-fledged political party, so I am delighted to have been chosen as our Interim Leader.ldquoIf we are to deliver on our ambition to change politics for the better, it is vital that we attract support from people from every walk of le, every political background and none."Coming into the House of Commons from running my manufacturing business in , I have seen with my own eyes how improved our political system would beit harnessed the erse skills and experience of our country.ldquoWe in Change UK, as we hope to be known, dont just dream about a fairer and better future for our country, we are determined to unleash it through hard work, passion and shared endeavour.Former Labour MP Chuka Umunna, the group spokesperson, added: ldquoThere is clearly an appetite for an alternative to our broken politics which needs fundamental change, as shown by the disastrous Brexit process which has occurred under the watch of the two main parties.ldquoA new party will shake up the two-party system and provide people with an alternative that can change our country for the better. This is what Change UK will be aiming to do at any European electionsour application for registration is accepted in time.ldquoThe Independent Group is a erse group of MPs which reflects modern Britain, drawn from dferent generations and backgrounds including a former GP, teacher, lecturer, social worker, solicitor and TV presenter."We intend to draw on all the voices of our group in any European election campaign. We will seek to put forward a substantial number of MEP candidates with backgrounds from outside of politics.The TIG MPs left their respective parties in February in protest at Theresa Mays handling of Brexit and Jeremy Corbyns handling of Brexit and anti-Semitism.

title: change-uk-who-are-they-and-how-are-they-linked-to-the-independent-group
story: Read more:New political party Change UK registered to fight European electionsChange UK is formed of eight former Labour MPs and three former Conservative MPs.From Labour: Chuka Umunna, Gavin Shuker, Luciana Berger, Ann Coffey, Mike Gapes, Chris Leslie, Joan Ryan and Angela Smith have joined.Anna Soubry, Sarah Wollaston and Heidi Allen are the three from the Conservative Party.Former Tory Heidi Allen has been selected as the interim leader of Change UK.The group say that the process for an election of the permanent leader will be announced in due course.Heidi Allen left the Conservative Party for the Independent Group in February, and renounced her membership of the Tories after they allowed a "hard-line anti-EU awkward squad" to take over the party.In full: Resignation letter of Anna Soubry, Sarah Wollaston and Heidi AllenShe said:ldquoToday marks a huge step forward on The Independent Grouprsquos journey to becoming a fully-fledged political party, so I am delighted to have been chosen as our interim leader."The group have registered as a political party in order to be able to fight European electionsthey take place this year.Weve done this in order to stand candidates in any European elections that come about as a result of a long extension of the Article  process, and we hope to shake up the two-party system and provide people with an alternative that can change our country for the better.If there is a further delay to Brexit, the UK will have to take part in the European Parliament elections on May .It means that they could have candidates in the elections.Since theyre not an official party yet, they havent published a manesto. They have, however, given an overview of their values.These include removing the barriers of poverty, prejudice and discrimination that face iniduals in Britain, acting on the urgency of climate change and giving more powers and representation to local governments.The group initially bonded over their shared drive to prevent a no-deal Brexit.Several members had been working together in the months leading up to the breakaway on the Peoples Vote campaign.Its not known yet where they stand on Scottish Independence, but several members have voiced concerns about what Brexit will mean for Scotland.Just hours after the party registration was announced, Anna Soubry said she was concerned that Brexit will increase the desire for Scotland to break away from the union.At the moment, there are no public plans in place by the group on what will happen in the event of a general election.They have said, however, that specic arrangements will be made and announced in the event of a snap election being called before the inaugural conference of Change UK in September.

title: snp-mp-calls-labour-idiots-on-the-wrong-side-of-history
story: Speaking in the House of Commons debating chamber, Deirdre Brock, MP for Edinburgh North and Leith, also branded the vote on Theresa Mays EU Withdrawal Deal "a pile of manure".This is my three minute speech from todays #Brexit debate. A more vicious version of the Bullingdon Club might be the next UK Government. It is time ask the people whether they approve of what they see https:t.co coQoyPydShe said: "We have a prime minister that thinks no will turn to yesyou only ask half of the question.:Brexit Withdrawal Agreement: Live updates as MPs set for crucial vote in Commons"And worse is to comeshe ever manages to muster enough support to resign to be replaced by a more vicious version of the Bullingdon club."Ms Brock added: "They stand on the wrong side of history and on the interests of people they represent."And on the vote, she says: "This pile of manure we are being offered is the appetiser of the slurry to come."Her comments come after a number of Tory and Labour MPS declared their support for Mrs Mays deal.Follow our live blog forupdates, comment and analysis on todaysWithdrawal Deal vote.

title: changeorg-uk-seeking-guidance-over-new-political-party-name
story: It was announced on Friday morning that the group had applied to become an official political party under the name Change UK.Read more:New political party Change UK registered to fight European electionsBut the name bears similarity to popular petitions site Change.org UK, and the company have said they are looking for advice.They took to Twitter on Friday afternoon after a memberof The Independent Group mistakenly referred to her new party by the wrong name.Read more:Who are Change UK and how are they linked to the Independent Group  Anna Soubry was speaking in the Commons when she introduced her party as Change.org.She said: "Change will come because change has to come. British politics is broken."I am delighted today that the group that Ive joined with members formely of the Labour party, has now formed itself into a new political party, that will change the face and direction of British politics."That is why we call ourselves change.org."A spokesman for change.org said on Twitter: "http:Change.org UK or @UKChange is a movement of  million people in the UK.https:t.co lZhnGWRD UK or @UKChange is a movement of  million people in the UK. We empower ordinary people to start petitions  campaign to create the change they want to see. Our petition starters, like Laura Coryton who ended the tampon tax and Richard Ratclfe "We empower ordinary people to start petitions  campaign to create the change they want to see. Our petition starters, like Laura Coryton who ended the tampon tax and Richard Ratclfefighting for the freedom of his we Nazanin, are disrupting the status quo of power in politics."http:Change.org UK or @UKChange as we are interchangeably known, is totally independent of party politics, always has been and always will be.They added: "Its said that imitation is a form of flattery."But the movement weve built in the UK to win campaigns for ordinary people is ours - all  million of us."We are seeking guidance on the proposed use of our brand name by those reported to be setting up a new political party."

title: brexit-vote-mps-reject-theresa-mays-withdrawal-agreement
story: It comes on the day Britain was originally supposed to leave the EU: March .MPs were considering the withdrawal agreement in todays debate and vote, which is the legal binding "orce deal" covering the UKs exit from the EU.Read more: Brexit Withdrawal Agreement as it happensAnd the Commons have rejected this motion with a majority of .This means that the UK will now be leaving the EU on April   days before we would have leftMPs had accepted the Withdrawal Agreement.Labour had whipped MPs not to support the deal, and the DUP had also said they would vote against the agreement.In order to win the vote, the Prime Minister hadto receive  more votes than it did last time, assuming MPs voted in the same way.Withdrawal Agreement debate: How many votes does Theresa May need to win The meaningful vote was lost last time with  in favour and  against, with just one MP absent.The Prime Minister said: "The implications of the Housesdecision are grave."The EU has been clear that any further extension will need to be agreed unamiously."It is almost certain to involve the UK being required to hold European Prliamentary elections."Jeremy Corbyn called on the Prime Minister to resign after the third rejection.In full: Who voted for and against Theresa Mays Brexit dealHe said: "This is now the third time the Prime Ministers deal has been rejected."This deal now has to change."If the Prime Minister cant accept that, she must go, so that we can decide the future of this country through a general election."Nicola Sturgeon also reacted to the news, and said that the SNP would now work with others to find the best option possible.Third defeat for PMrsquos bad deal - she must now accept that itrsquos dead. The Commons will nowon Monday to find a way forward. I hope that willl be to put the issue back to the people and or revoke Article  - but @theSNP will work with others to find the best option possiblePresident Donald Tusk called for a meeting of the European Council just moments after the result was announced.In view of the rejection of the Withdrawal Agreement by the House of Commons, I have decided to call a European Council on  April. #BrexitThe meeting is set for just two days before the UK is now expected to leave the EU.

title: swing-into-action-at-some-of-the-best-golf-courses
story: Are you ready to tee off in some of thebest courses in Scotland and Northern Ireland Take inspiration from theupcoming championship and try out some fantastic golf courses for yourself.Golf in Northern IrelandNorthern Ireland is home to some of the most spectacular golf courses in the world, including Royal Portrush, host of The th Open and Royal County Down, voted No  course in the world by readers of Golf Digest. These courses have seen home-grown talent including Rory McIlroy, Graeme McDowell and Darren Clarke hone their skills and rise to stardom thanks to the spectacular quality of their local greens and fairways.Getting to Northern Ireland from Scotland couldnrsquot be easier and with just a short hop across the water you too could be following in the footsteps of these golfing legends and making the most of the fantastic range of links and parkland courses Northern Ireland has to offer.Portstewart Golf ClubTwo-time Open champion Willie Park Jr was responsible for one of the makeovers of Portstewart Golf Clubrsquos Strand Course, which lies just  minutes from Royal Portrush and which staged the  Dubai Duty Free Irish Open. Its  holes of links golf include the Riverside Course and the original Old Course, dating from .Ardglass Golf ClubAfter a round on the short but spectacular Ardglass Golf Club links, hugging the rocky shore and clfs close to Royal County Down, golfers can raise a glass in the bar of the worldrsquos oldest clubhouse, built as a castle more than  years ago and with cannons pointing out over the fairways just in front.Royal Belfast Golf ClubRoyal Belfast Golf Club, only  minutes from Belfast city centre, was founded in  and is Irelandrsquos oldest golf club. It was granted royal patronage in  by Edward, Prince of Wales, the future King Edward VII. The club moved to its present location on the shores of Belfast Lough after World War I and its new -hole course was designed by Harry Colt, opening in .Holywood Golf ClubJust  miles outside of Belfast, Holywood Golf Club is where champion Rory McIlroy honed his skills as a youngster. A special area of the clubhouse is a shrine to the clubrsquos favourite son, with memorabilia including photographs of his early years playing there and replicas of the US Open and US PGA trophies. The clubhouse has been undergoing major renovation to add a new gym and indoor practice facilities. A new th green and floodlit putting green have also been created.Galgorm Castle Golf ClubNorthern Ireland Open host venue Galgorm Castle Golf Club is laid out through mature wooded grounds in the heart of the -acre Galgorm Castle Estate in Ballymena, alongside its th century castle.Check out Ireland golf for Northern Ireland golfing breaks.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Golf at Trump TurnberryRecently voted Best Golf Resort in Europe , adding to other achievements including leading Golf Hotel of the Year, Trump Turnberry, a Luxury Collection Resort, is home to two outstanding courses and state of the art golf academy.The iconic Open Championship Ailsa course has regularly ranked number one golf course in the UK and Ireland. Set alongside the stunning Ayrshire coastline with the backdrop of the Ailsa Craig, this is a course that leaves lasting memories. Book now for a last minute April golf breaks from pound per person and enjoy a one night stay in luxurious accommodation, breakfast and round on the Open Championship Ailsa course.Trump Turnberry is also home to the award winning King Robert the Bruce course. Reborn in , this magnicent course by Martin Ebert is a thrill for golfers of all levels. Players enjoy outstanding views of the coastline and the Turnberry Lighthouse, including the ruins of King Robert the Brucersquos castle.For those wanting to take part in one of the ious competitions while trying out the spectacular King Robert the Bruce course, there is the Autumn Festival on Saturday  and Sunday  October. This two man team event comprises of an inidual stableford on the Saturday followed by a better ball on the Sunday with the chance to win a two night stay at Pine Clfs, a Luxury Collection Resort, Algarve. Priced at only pound per person including an overnight stay, breakfast and two rounds on King Robert the Bruce.Take part in one of the ious events happening throughout the year including lsquoTurnberry from the Tipsrsquo on Friday  April, lsquoKing Robert the Bruce Openrsquo on Friday  May and Junior Camps running through Easter and summer.Visit the website for full details at www.turnberry, call+   or emailteetimes@trumpturnberry--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Cardross Golf ClubConsidered one of the finest parkland courses in the West of Scotland, Cardross offers a memorable and challenging golf experience for members and visitors alike. Founded in , the current golf course layout benefited from design changes recommended by James Braid, which were implemented in . The Club enjoys reciprocal agreements with fellow members of the Association of James Braid Courses and the  Club.Cardross has long been regarded as a top championship course and has played host to the Scottish Professional Championships in , which was won by the then future British Open Champion Paul Lawrie. More recently, it has hosted the Scottish Ladies Junior Open Strokeplay Championship in  and the Scottish Boys Open Amateur Strokeplay Championship in .Generous undulating fairways, large deciduous The arresting views across to the islands of Islay, Jura and Gigha provide a delightful backdrop on an idyllic summers day with the firm Machrihanish turf underfoot, the majesty of the dunes and wheeling seabirds providing the musical sound track.To provide a ied test for the competent golfer, the layout is not just a predictable nine out and nine back. The classic links holes, apart from the st, are the th, another par four with its fairway like an elephants graveyard, the th, a clever dogleg par five and the th, a "one shotter" with real dficultythe elusive green is missed from the tee. Members can also enjoy complimentary use of the practise and putting areas.The course ranks highly on a global scale. Golf Digest rated Machrihanish among the top  courses in the world in , climbing  places to now rank st in the world. The club is also rated fourth best value for money within the UK.To find out more about the club, visit www.machgolf golfclubvideo.php---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------BurntislandDating back to , the original Burntisland Golf Club is officially recognised as the tenth oldest golf club in the world. The new course at Dodheadwas first surveyed by Old Tom Morris designed by Willie Park Jnr in  and later updated by legendary golf course architect, James Braid in .Although not the longest golf course, Burntisland offers a iety of unique challenges to golfers of all abilities. A largely flat, links-style golf course, Burntisland features short climbs and descents. Its tight fairways, fast greens and natural hazards are a true test of nerve and skill.The course also boasts plenty of great seaward views from many of the vantage points with Arthurrsquos Seat, EdinburghCastle, the Bass Rock and Berwick Law all easily recognisable across the water, as well as the Forth Bridges to the west.The relaxing clubhouse offers a comfortable lounge and dining area. The Club provides daily menus based on locally sourced ingredients to suit all tastes and budgets, and has the experience and expertise to cater for a iety of events throughout the year, with hospitality renowned as being second to none.Burntisland Golf House Club is very popular with visiting societies with many ing annually. Renowned for its friendly atmosphere, all parties are promised a warm welcome.Society groups can choose from a ious tailor-made packages which combine excellent golf on the well-conditioned course and delicious dining options.Come and walk in the footsteps of legends.Visit the websitewww.burntislandgolfhouseclub or Facebook page to find out more.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------St MichaelsSt Michaels is an -hole, par- course within sight of the historic town of St Andrews. The front nine holes overlook the Eden Estuary and the spired churches of St. Andrews can be seen on the horizon during play. story: MPs rejected the Prime Ministers deal with a majority of  on Friday afternoon, meaning the UK will be leaving the EU on April .Read more:MPs reject Theresa Mays Withdrawal AgreementPresident Donald Tusk has called for a summit to be held two days before the exit date.The EU Commission say that in light of the rejection, a no-deal scenario is very likely.They say they have been preparing for this scenario for the last two years, and now they are ready.Read more:Brexit Withdrawal Agreement as it happenedA spokesperson said: "The Commission regrets the negative vote in the House of Commons today."A ldquono-deal scenario on  April is now a likely scenario."The EU has been preparing for this since December  and is now fully prepared for a ldquono-deal scenario at midnight on  April.In full: Who voted for and against Theresa Mays Brexit dealThey added: "The EU will remain united."The benefits of the Withdrawal Agreement, including a transition period, will in no circumstances be replicated in a ldquono-deal scenario."

title: hopes-for-scottish-herring-recovery-as-huge-spawning-shoals-spotted
story: Herring was the leblood of coastal communities right up until the Second World War until the fatty fish was almost killed off.Now, for the first time ever, huge shoals of spring spawning herring off the north-west of the country, sparking feint hopes that stocks might one day recover.The images were captured close to Gairloch for the BBCrsquos ground-breaking Blue Planet UK series broadcast on Friday.Local fishermen have been watching the fish throughout the month of March, suggesting they were were likely to spawn in the area.These Atlantic herring, which once underpinned a thriving west coast industry, have remained at historically low levels for years.Populations of the fish across Scotland collapsed in the s and s, and although there has been a gradual increase in North Sea herring, west coast stocks are still recovering from decades of over-exploitation.Nick Underdown of the campaign group Open Seas said: ldquoShoals of fish ing to spawn in Gairloch is hugely exciting. Given the boom and bust history of the herring fishery, these fish need all the help they can get.ldquoHerring are one of the foundations of healthy seas. If the stock was to recover on the west coast it could underpin the future of our fishing industry and rural communities for decades to come. Spawning grounds are precious and we are urging the Scottish Government to protect the full, known extent of the herring spawning ground in Gairloch.Every year herring swim from deep offshore seas towards our coasts where each female fish lays tens of thousands of eggs.The eggs stick to the seabed and after a few weeks develop into fish larvae - the next generation.Herring spawning used to take place in such huge numbers that there are tales of the waters turning white with fish eggs.Such massive spawning events give food to seals, seabirds, dolphins and other fish, and where stocks are healthy, such as in Canada, these events still bring in huge numbers of other marine wildle. A famous spawning ground in Gairloch has been closed to bottom-towed fishing, such as prawn-trawling and scallop dredging, for over  years.West coast herring stocks continue to decline and the International Council for the Exploration of the Seasays that all measures should be taken to protect the places where herring spawn to improve their chances for the future.

title: campaigner says kintore station must open as soon as possible
story: A local councillor who has played a leading role in the campaign for a Kintore station has said it must be completed as soon as possible and opened with the minimum delay.A delay in the expected opening date for the new station was announced in mid-March when Aberdeenshire Councils Infrastructure Services Committee received a briefing from Network Rail on the current railway works between Aberdeen and Inverurie.Commenting East Garioch cllr Martin Ford said: "I am surprised and disappointed that Transport Scotland is now indicating May  as their date for opening the new Kintore station. A planned opening date of December  has been in the public domain for many years without the rail industry expressing any alternative view."The dates of December  and May  are signicant because these are the points in the year when new rail timetables are introduced.Representatives of Network Rail attended a meeting of Kintore Community Council last week where the delay to the expected station opening date was not well received. Cllr Martin Ford was present at the meeting along with other Aberdeenshire councillors and community councillors.Cllr Ford added: "What I still want to see is Kintore station included in the December  rail timetable. If it isnt, the station cant open until the start of the next timetable in May  – evenall the building work is finished well before that."So put Kintore station in the December  timetable but with a note against it: Station under construction and expected to open during the currency of this timetable – see local announcements. That has been done where to allow new stations to be opened as soon as they are ready on completion of construction work."Its then up to Transport Scotland, Network Rail and the contractors to get the station finished as quickly as they can, so it can open as soon as possible, albeit after December  but before May ."It is believed that since Cllr Ford asked that Kintore station still be included in the December  timetable, Aberdeenshire Council transportation officers have made a similar request."We need Kintore station open and available for residents to use at the earliest possible date," said Cllr Ford.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Gordon MP Colin Clark with Allyn Harper and Bryan Harper"  MP visits Insch firm viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: upgrade to rail line means closures
story: Network Rail engineers will be working from May to August to complete a multi-million-pound upgrade to track and signalling between Aberdeen and Inverurie as part of the Aberdeen-Inverness Improvement Project.From May  to August , the railway will undergo a series of closures to allow engineers to double the track between Dyce and Inverurie, carry out bridge upgrades and deliver signalling enhancements.The following service alterations will be in place during the upgrade works: May –June : Buses replace trains between Dyce and Inverurie June –August : Buses replace trains between Dyce and Huntly August –August : Bus replace trains between Aberdeen and Inverness August –August : Buses replace trains between Aberdeen and Huntly.The work builds on the closure of the line between May and August  which saw the successful completion of the first phase of double-tracking between Aberdeen and Dyce.Funded by the Scottish Government, the Aberdeen-Inverness Improvement Project will reduce journey times and increase capacity on the route between the two cities.Billy McKay, Network Rail senior programme manager, said: “Double-tracking the line between Aberdeen and Inverurie will improve reliability on the route and allow a signicant increase in the number of services available to customers.“The project means more services, more seats and faster journeys for passengers. The benefits of the project for ScotRail customers include: a half-hourly service all day between Inverurie and Aberdeen from December , a new direct service between Inverurie and Montrose, reducing the need to change in Aberdeen.“We understand the inconvenience the work will cause to some passengers and residents, but such a project cannot be delivered without the closure of the line. We are encouraging customers to leave extra time for travel and plan journeys in advance.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Man for court following Pittodrie incident viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: arctic team set out to retrace orcadian explorers steps
story: A four-man expedition team are making their final preparations as they set out to retrace Orcadian arctic explorer Dr John Rae#s footsteps.Canada-based Scot David Reid will lead the expedition, along with filmmaker Gary Tutte, fellow Scot Richard Smith and Frank Wolf, trekking  miles from Naujaatin Canada, across Booth Peninsula to Rae Strait — the stretch of water named after Rae.It will be the same route covered by Rae during his  exploration — paying tribute to and raising awareness of the explorer#s achievements.The quartet is due to begin their -day journey next week, hauling -kilogram sledges for up to nine hours each day.Rae is credited with discovering the missing link of the shipping lane, the Northwest Passage, and discovering the fate of Capt Sir John Franklin#s ill-fated expedition of  when he and his entire crew died.It was Rae#s findings, reporting that Franklin#s crew had resorted to cannibalism in a last desperate attempt to stay alive, which horried Victorian society, leading to Rae and his achievements being condemned to obscurity.Mr Smith said: “The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history.#It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae’s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Orphir.#Keep up-to-date with the group#s progress on their website: www.arcticcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: carmichael no deal catastrophic for livestock farmers and crofters
story: The MP for Orkney and Shetland, Alistair Carmichael, has challenged the UK Government’s #no deal# planning which he described as “catastrophic” for rural communities.Speaking in the House of Commons today, Mr Carmichael, who is the Liberal Democrat DEFRA spokesperson, said: “Can I tell the minister that I very much agree with him when he talks of Europe as a key export market for our lamb producers and hill farmers.# of his colleagues last night voted for a no deal Brexit, including the Hon. Member who asked the questiona no deal Brexit could expose lamb exports to a . per cent plus €. kg tarf. Is that going to be good for our sheep farmers ”Responding on behalf of the government, the Rt. Hon. Robert Goodwill, minister of state for fishing and farming, said: #The best way to prevent a situation in which we have a no deal Brexit is to vote for the deal. Nothing yesterday was supported by the House. The deal is the best thing for agriculture, the best thing for the future, and the best thing for a long-term relationship between ourselves and the European Union.Speaking after the exchange, Mr Carmichael added: “For Brexiteers to talk about the post-Brexit agriculture industry being of #paramount importance# while cheerfully voting for a #no deal# Brexit that could destroy it, smacks of hypocrisy. Our farmers and crofters need to realise that those who promote #no-deal# Brexit are not on their side. They are prepared to damage the livelihoods of our livestock farmers and crofters to pursue their Brexit unicorns.“The test for any deal the government comes back with for our rural communities, must be whether it allows them to continue to access key European export markets. No-deal clearly fails that fundamental test and will make our farmers and crofters worse off.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: drifting bulk carrier now repaired and underway
story: Repairs have been successfully carried out onboard a bulk carrier which suffered engine failure and was drting in the Pentland Firth last night.A Coastguard statement said: #Just before .pm yesterday, Thursday, HM Coastguard received a report that the bulk carrier Leo Iris had suffered engine failure and was drting in the Pentland Firth.#With poor weather conditions on scene, HM Coastguard immediately called in the ETV . They kept  minute welfare checks with the Leo Iris and also informed the duty SOSREPand the MCA’s Counter Pollution Team.#Temporary repairs were made to the vessel and it was able to manoeuvre clear of the Pentland Firth to an anchorage position to the east of South Ronaldsay. The ETV stood by the vessel until it was repaired and underway.#Giving a further update on the situation, the Coastguard added this morning: #Repairs continued to be made to the vessel, and just after .am HM Coastguard was informed that the vessel had been fully repaired and was preparing to restart its journey. The vessel has now weighed anchor and is safely underway.#It is understood that the ship is on a voyage between Norfolk, USA, to Swinoujscie, Poland.• During the incident Longhope Leboat crew were paged at .pm, the boat was made ready and requested to standby by the Coastguard, as the , tonne ship was adrt north-west of Stroma.The crew was stood down at . when it was confirmed by the Coastguard that  temporary repairs had been made and the ship was out of danger.Coxswain, Angus Budge, said: #This is a good example of a potentially very serious situation where the volunteer crew are ready to respond.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: exciting times ahead for stromness
story: Stromness Community Development Trust is on the hunt for a development officer and board members as it seeks to develop a #dynamic plan# for the town#s future.An officer will be now be employed by the trust to support the development, sustainability and wellbeing of Stromness, working in partnership with key stakeholders to support the delivery of a range of community projects in the town.Funding for the post had come through Orkney Islands Council’s economic development service and the local LEADER fund.Additional board members are also being sought for the trust to oversee the work of the development officer and help plan for future projects.Kris Bevan is chair of the Stromness Community Development Trust. He said: “We’re now looking for a development officer with the drive and enthusiasm to support the development, sustainability and wellbeing of Stromness.#We are also looking to recruit directors to the board of the trust. title: free sanitary products to be offered in more public buildings
story: Free sanitary products are to be made available in a range of public buildings in Orkney from next month onwards.This follows on from August last year, when the Scottish Government made funding available to supply free products in schools, colleges and universities.This scheme is now being extended, with the council and Orkney’s community planning partners to begin stocking free products in other facilities including community centres, libraries, the new hospital and from a range of voluntary sector organisations.The products available will be regular sanitary pads, tampons and night-time sanitary pads.The council has explained that the main aims of the scheme are to tackle what is known as #period poverty# and protect people#s dignity by making a range of products available in places that people use, ensuring anyone who menstruates can access sufficient amounts of these products, including transgender men non-binary iniduals.Hayley Green is the council#s head of buildings and facilities. She said: #In its  Programme for Government, the Scottish Government made a commitment to increase the number and range of places where sanitary products are available for those who need them.#Sanitary products are not a luxury product, they are a necessity for a very large part of someone#s le. We want to encourage people who need them to take the products — taking enough for their entire period, not just for that day. title: judges decision due on ferry contract legality
story: A senior judge is set to issue his decision on whether a proposed £ million Scottish Government contract to provide ferries to the northern isles is unlawful.Lord Boyd will issue his judgement on whether the Scottish Ministers are breaching strict EU competition rules over the matter in the near future.The judge has spent the past two days sitting in the Court of Session, in Edinburgh, listening to legal arguments brought by Pentland Ferries.Lawyers for the company claim the Scottish Government is acting unlawfully in its plans to attract companies to operate sailings between the mainland and Orkney and Shetland.The Scottish Ministers are offering to subsidise the business which wins a tendering process to provide the services.Three firms — CalMac Ferries Ltd, Forde Reederei Seetouristik GmbH and the business currently operating the route Serco Northlink Ltd — are currently bidding to win the contract.However, Pentland Ferries, which currently operates a service between Gills Bay in Caithness and St Margaret’s Hope in Orkney, believes the proposed £ million subsidy is unlawful.The company decided to go to Scotland’s highest civil court after an announcement from the Scottish Government last month.Speaking about the proposed subsidy on Tuesday, Pentland’s advocate Mark Lindsay QC said: “This is viewed as an existential threat by the petitioner who is concerned that they will no longer be able to trade. The subsidy is unlawful state aid and it will disturb the market.”The company decided to go to Scotland’s highest civil court after an announcement from the Scottish Government last month. The ministers had decided to name three companies who are bidding to provide ferry services between Aberdeen and Orkney and Shetland.Final tenders for the contract are expected to be submitted by the end of April  and the successful firm will receive a subsidy estimated to be worth around £ million.Legal papers lodged in the case show that Pentland Ferries seeks a declarator from the court that the proposed subsidy is unlawful and breaches obligations placed upon the government by EU law.Today saw lawyers for the Scottish government argued that the ministers had acted lawfully.Having finished hearing from both sides, Lord Boyd said he’d issue his decision at some point in the near future.See next Thursday#s edition of The Orcadian for the full story.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney part of pioneering new leisure partnership
story: In what is believed to be the first of its kind in Scotland, a new leisure link partnership will see ActiveLe members enjoy access to leisure facilities outwith Orkney for the first time.The scheme will see ActiveLe members have access to gym, public swimming and fitness classes at facilities across the Highland region, Moray, the Western Isles, and Argyll and Bute at no extra cost.Known as the Leisure Link Partnership, many of the inidual Leisure Link Partnership sites will also offer access to other public sessions where cardholders can take part in many other activities such as running and indoor climbing.The Leisure Link Partnership means that when working away from home or on holiday members from participating areas can, at no extra cost, use the local facilities as part of their existing home-based membership.James Linklater, managing director of The Pickaquoy Centre, said: “We are delighted to be part of this new partnership which is a fantastic addition to the ActiveLe membership.
